149610722.review:
I just finished this game with the good ending. I am going to replay it with a guide at some point to get the true ending but my review is going to be based on the route to the good ending.

[h1]THE STORY[/h1]

I have played the other Re;Birth games already and I had high hopes for this game. With the exception of 1 part of the story I didn't really like ( I will go into that more later ), this game delivered. All the new characters were pretty interesting and seeing a lot of returning characters was really great as well. The plot was well written and there were some twist that I honestly did not see coming.

So now I will briefly talk about the one part I did not like. This is sort of a spoiler so only read it if you don't mind a minor spoiler. [spoiler] This game treats Nepgear like garbage. She is the but of every joke for half the game. They make several references to Re;Birth 2 where she was the main character and mention how weak she was as a main. I actually really like Nepgear and I really enjoyed the second game. I don't know why Idea Factory seems to hate one of there own characters that much. If it was only a few Nepgear jokes that wouldn't be that bad but she is treated pretty awful in this game, even by Neptune. [/spoiler]

[h1]GAMEPLAY[/h1]

This game is mostly the same as the first 2 games in game play but takes some steps backwards. The biggest change that I definitely did not like is that literally nobody but the main characters get EX moves and the main characters only get team up moves and no solo moves. I don't feel this was because my level was too low because all my characters were past level 90 by the end of the game. It also felt like it took longer to recover SP after EX moves which will make you not want to use them at all. The coupling moves will take even longer to recover since not only do you need to recover SP for the character that started the move but also the other character that is not active at the time.

This game did add some cool gimmicks that were not in the other games. One is these hidden blocks that you have to hit with your head, Mario style. I also felt like the jump was more useful in this game than other games.  There were alot more interactions you could have at the Basilicom including 1 on 1 interactions with Neptune herself. They even added a quiz game show in where you could win a crap ton of money playing ( DO NOT SKIP THESE )

[h1]GRAPHICS[/h1]

The graphics are mostly just reused assets from the previous games. There was a lot more variety in the areas you could explore which was a welcome change. The only complaint I have about the graphics is the change in the battle UI. It looks noticeably worst than the previous games. But that is just my opinion and you may like its simplicity more than I did. You will get used to it but it is the one thing that will stick out if you are coming into this game fresh off the last game.

[h1]OVERALL[/h1]

Overall, I think this is a solid game. I like all the new characters, the story was interesting, and it maintains the addicting the gameplay of the first 2 games. I personally like Re;Birth 2 a little more but I still think this game is definitely worth checking out.

147314594.review:
Now that I finally got all the achievements for this Neptunia game in particular, I can say it's my long time favorite game of the series (played it before, just another platform), and clearly better than Re;Birth 1 and 2, being the most polished game of the trilogy. Because, let's be honest, Re;Birth 1 destroys the original story in a disgusting way, so it's the worst version of the Superdimension story, with Victory gameplay and that's it. And Re;Birth 2 is just mk2 with a few changes, more makers, but it's still the same game with the same boring protagonist and repetitive story about piracy being bad and people praising it cuz of a forced edgy ahh ending.

Re;Birth 3/Victory on the other hand, brought a better and more enjoyable story, with a good amount of new characters with solid interactions and fun moments, no exe drive gauge so you need more strategy, a better version of Stella's Dungeon (R;B3 only), and overall, it's the most enjoyable one. The reason why it's hated by a lot of people is because of TWO. THINGS. yes, only that.

The first one is how Nepgear is treated in this game, this was because people found Nepgear as a boring ahh Neptune with depression and self-confidence lil' girl back when mk2 was released, so she's always made fun of during the game cuz of that and only that (and just a few moments). Nepgear fans can't just accept that, they just cry about it and say this game sucks only cuz of their character getting a non-protagonist treatment.

The other thing is; Plutia/Iris Heart, probably one of the most important characters. People complain about Iris Heart and her questionable behavior, but entirely ignore that she was really important, she saved Blanc, she saved Peashy, she saved the dimensions, she's better than what you think, stop ignoring the good things she did.

Anyway, I really recommend this game, pretty solid Neptunia game with funny moments and an epic story filled with references (as always).

147171300.review:
If you like classic rpgs, dont buy this (and probably other neptunia rpgs), specially without a big discount. Is extremely expensive in time, and in money even with a huge discount, relative to the amount and quality of content. dont let the rating blind you: i made that mistake, but still wanted to give it a chance, so i completed almost everything in the game (even if steam didnt registered all the "archivements")

The positive:
Maybe a few jokes or game design elments included to parody (mainly) known japanese videogame companies. This imo is not enough to recommend this, or any other game in this series with similar design. If you are curious about the general plot and style of the dialogues, a better option would be watching the anime.

The negative:
Almost everything else: the music becomes boring from lack of variety; same problem with dungeons, which feel like copy+pasta, and closer in design to extremely low budget and generic dungeon crawlers (and probably worse). The gameplay is very repetitive, and the game becomes grindy with little reward. The game works and feels more like a "visual novel with extra steps" than an rpg with minor visual novel elements (ie persona games). There little immersion outside dungeons, and you will spend most time surfing in-game menus that represent interactions (ie towns are menus).

Also the game lacks mods that maybe could improve a bit the experience and reduce its simplistic nature. 

There are so many cheap rpg games with far better storytelling and quality in script to choose before this one, that spending time in this one is as bad as doing physical damage to yourself. If a gatcha game could become an undercover assasin, neptunia games would be that assassin (so its also a bit like a gatcha game without the typical huge amount of micro-transactions).

146979849.review:
[h1] Story [/h1] (9/10)
If I may say that the story of Neptunia Rebirth 3 is the best compared to the two previous series. Starting from the plot of Neptune who was transported to another dimension and it turned out to be a game industry from a different universe. There it turns out that Neptune again has to defeat an evil boss called the Seven Sages. with the help of the new character Plutia (iris heart) together they defeat the seven sages up to the final boss rei. very amazing story. so many new characters, especially in terms of bosses, are very good, making this game very exciting to play


[h1] Graphic [/h1] (9/10)
The characters in the game Neptunia Rebirth 3 are very varied compared to the two previous series, the description of the boss is very interesting, like a mecha robot. And again, in Neptunia Rebirth 3 there are two new CPUs, namely Iris Heart and Yellow Heart. Rei can even be a CPU in its HDD form. making this game even more exciting with so many new characters


[h1] Gameplay [/h1] (8/10)
I really praise the gameplay this time. The gameplay in Neptunia Rebirth 3 has progressed quite a bit. The first thing that is interesting is that the number of playable characters that can be accessed at the start of the game is already large. so that leveling becomes easier, rather than appearing one by one according to the storyline. secondly, the UI of this game has improved a lot, so it is better to look at and understand, then the downside is that in general it is still the typical Neptunia combo and the addition of challenges that require you to do them to get skills. This of course adds unnecessary grinding, making the game quite boring.


[h1] Sound [/h1] (7/10)
The sound of this game is still the same as the two previous series, so it doesn't feel like there's anything different, like a big DLC ​​instead. So the developer should add new sounds to make the game experience more exciting

[h1] DLC [/h1] (8/10)
There are many and various types of DLC in this game. Starting from DLC about new areas, new quests, new items, even DLC to get new characters which of course helps players to get achievements.

146318913.review:
It says I've played for 12 hours, but I've actually played for 56 hours for my first play-through.  This review is more-so based on the PS3 version "Hyperdimension Neptunia Victory" that this is based off of, but I've played enough of this version of the game to explain the differences and tell if this is still worth while or not.  Let's start with the pros:

- The combat is outstandingly designed, a lot of fun, and can be incredibly deep.

- Bosses/Boss fights are hard, but in the best way possible (at least in my opinion).

- The humor is OUTSTANDING and as good here as it is in any other Neptunia game.


All in all, this game is a blast if you understand the combat.  There aren't a lot of pros, but the quality of the pros MORE than makes up for the lack of quantity.  Now for the cons:


- Assets are ruthlessly re-used.  This is nothing new for Neptunia, but it positively hampers the experience a lot more than it should...  This includes dungeon layouts, enemy designs, and even bosses.  It really does eliminate the element of exploring, and finding anything that's really new.  I don't mean to go on and on about it, but this really is (and always has been) Neptunia's greatest weakness...  I really hope this changes, because I sincerely believe these games would be a lot more popular if it does...

- The story is nothing special, but it is interesting enough to keep you engaged and invested.

- This version of the game gives you access to many characters that you realistically shouldn't have access to.  There's a point in the game VERY early on where you have like 10 different cutscenes and each one gives you a new party character that you realistically shouldn't have.  I understand that they wanted to make the game easier and more accessible, but this is a very strange way of doing that.  Especially when they give you access to Histoire who's strong enough to basically beat the entire game if you just use her.  A difficulty setting is how you do this correctly; not throwing 10+ party members at players randomly.

- A few cutscenes drag on longer than they need to.  Specifically cutscenes before major boss fights.  You have the option to skip these, but for those who listen to the dialogue (which in a perfect world is everyone) it makes situations harder to take seriously since they just drag things out.  Despite this, I STRONGLY discourage you from skipping any dialogue that you haven't already seen.

Overall, this is still an OUTSTANDING experience despite all of the shortcomings.  If you like anime, and Japanese humor, you'll certainly enjoy this.  And if you're a fan of the series, you really do need to play this.  One more thing I'll say is that the anime uses a very similar plot to this game, but this game is a MUCH more complete version of the plot and has enough differences to make it really interesting and worth your while.  Honestly, this is the DEFINITIVE version of the plot used in the anime by a long shot with LOADS more content.

P.S.
Don't be a impatient, SERIOUSLY read/listen to ALL of the cutscene dialogue!  For me, half of the fun in the Neptunia series IS the cutscenes, so don't cheat yourself out of half the fun if you paid full price (or even if you didn't...).

144320411.review:
More Nep goodness.

This time, rather than making a *complete* asset flip of a sequel, they opted to shake things up a bit, for better or for worse.
Pros:
+Playable oracles! And they're strong early on, which helps a lot
+Despite them not being a proper part of the story (a real shame), it manages to have *more* character development than usual for the Maker characters via side stories
+Finally, a mention of consoles outside the main 3
+Stella's Dungeon actually has a purpose now (though this is a double-edged sword, see below in Cons)
+Nepgear gets made fun of
+Neptune is playable from the start, which is how it should be
+Secret treasure system replaced with something far less irritating

Cons:
-It's an isekai. Enough said
-Stella's Dungeon. There's a ton of crap you might miss out on bc it's locked behind treasures in SD.
-EXE moves take forever to unlock unless you specifically grind for them (and even that is annoying), and now they all cost 3/4 of your SP or more
-EXE gauge and SP gauge being combined looks convenient at first, but gets REALLY annoying
-LOTS of characters from the previous game(s) that just don't show up in the story (or show up for a disappointingly brief amount of time)
-They brought back Warechu but not Underling, for reasons comprehensible only to Idea Factory
-It is ridiculously hard to get higher-tier Idea Chips for some reason
-Can no longer check stats of items in the shop against multiple characters at once

Also, a final thought: Unlike some others, I actually don't think Plutia is that poorly written, I like her a lot. What DOES need work is how they write everyone's reactions to her. THAT gets REALLY old.

140903167.review:
I'm not really the video game critique type of guy but I can't believe I am saying this to a nep game

The developers have tried to somewhat change the mechanics of the game and that's kinda fine but it is very detrimental to the gameplay process as a whole. Nep-nep games should be light-hearted and easy to pick up with the right amount of mechanics. Not too deep, but also not too shallow.

Requiring the player to grind more however backfires to the experience.  I am talking about the "Challenges" system which introduces small bonuses if you meet a certain criteria but they are not worth it, needless to say, they also don't contribute much to the overall gameplay. But then you notice that EXE skills are gated in this challenges and you begin to understand why I don't like it.

Grinding that 100 skill cast will add up on your gameplay and you might not even notice it. EXE skills can also be ignored as coupling EXE skills exists and can be unlocked by simply leveling. This type of mechanic introduces another set of needless grinding which is tedious. Furthermore, characters with high sp costs are more at disadvantage here. There are methods to do this quickly, some might even say I'm just crying, and yes I am. Previous nep rebirth games did not require you additional grinding to acquire EXE drive skills, it is acquired through leveling.

With that out of the way, this sequel also is buggy.
Sometimes world map elements can glitch out. Appearing black or missing textures.
Controls not working properly.
Softlocking mid-battle.

more bugs have also been experience by other players but the bugs above can be solved by re-launching the game.

Otherwise I still enjoyed the game, the characters, humor, and overall feeling of the game. It is still what you expect out of a nep-nep video game.

7/10

Also please give us the next mainline title, it has been 100 years since since VII.

138015769.review: I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

136699320.review:
What I liked:
* Turn based combat is solid.
* Story is hilarious with serious moments to maintain the tension.
* The characters are likable
* The difficulty is well balanced, not counting some deliberately hard side-quests, but that's intentional.
* The art-style is well made.

What I disliked
* To avoid crashes, you need to install a mod, but that can be found 4-GB patch in the community tab.
* Lack of a complete English Dub, but the re-translation mod, also in community tab fixes this. 

I recommend this game for any J-RPG fan looking for a long game with good game-play and fun writing.
Rating 8/10, the sequel, Megadimension Neptunia V-II is a much better game, but then again it came after this game, so I expected that to be the case.

🔵[b] Requires light tinkering [/b]

To fix resolution problem change the "high DPI settings" of the game executable:
- Find the game executable NeptuniaReBirth3.exe on your system (manage > browse local files).
- Right-click the executable, then select Properties.
- Switch to the Compatibility tab and click on Change high DPI settings, under "Settings".
- On the new window, under "High DPI scaling override", activate the checkbox: [✓].
- Select Application from the dropdown menu and confirm with OK.
- Click Apply, then OK on the Properties window.
- Launch the game.

- Game will start with mouse/keyboard controls (gamepad will not work). Navigate to options with touchscreen and change controls to gamepad.
- A and B button swapped by default for some reason. Rebind it in game options.

Tested on: OnexPlayer Mini Pro 6800U

En esta tercera entrega de la trilogía Re;Birth seguimos las andanzas de nuestras CPU's y el resto de personajes, el modo de contar la historia es el típico de la saga, estilo Visual Novel sin decisiones, Gráficos estilo anime típicos de la saga, voces en Ingles o Japonés y textos en Ingles, el modo de combate es el de siempre, RPG por turnos con un ligero toque action ya que te dejan moverte hacia el enemigo, puedes tener 4 personajes a la vez en combate más 4 personajes enlazados para cambiarlos en cualquier momento en mitad del combate lo cual te da más dinamismo a la hora de luchar gracias a los Rangos Lily típicos de la saga, las  habilidades y combos se ven muy bien y son muy épicos, hay gran variedad de personajes, así pues elige los que mas te gusten y a disfrutar.

118435693.review:
Finally went around to playing the latest installment of the rebirth series

+Just like the other games, the gameplay loops is the same and still fun. I much enjoyed the SP system of this game over having an EXE drive. It is a tad bit different that way and at first I was quite upset but it did make me actually use SP unlike the previous games.

+Finally we can have a 5th move in our arsenal for combat rather than just 4 moves. You still start with 4 moves but you can unlock a 5th move through challenges. You won't have it for every character but it's nice to have.

+Finally removed the dumb treasure revealing shenanigans the previous installments had. This mechanic was trash and no one found anything with it without Laplace's eye. I didn't realize how happy I would be now that we had mario blocks instead of the dumb Treasure finding shenanigans.

+On this note, the new challenge system is nice as we get mini-achievements throughout our playthrough. It does feel satisfying and it definitely feels like a well-made system. I am upset some things are locked behind the challenges but overall this was an upgrade from the previous title. There may be a tad bit too many challenges tho.

+The plan system is still the fun resource that we know and love that changes the game and adds to the grind. It is still the same plan system as ever with nothing new but it still is nice to have. Again still super important as lots of stuff is locked behind plans.

+I found the story to be on par with rebirth 1 or even better. Definitely infinitely better than the story of rebirth 2. I am happy to say they didn't go downhill from the story of rebirth 2. The main cast having Plutia definitely made the experience much more entertaining. I am happy to say this one kept me entertained as Neptune meets the same people but in a different dimension. Maybe I feel this way since rebirth 2 story was just boring since the main cast wasn't as good.

+The world is still filled with a lot of references from different games and is still fun to read through all the unimportant dialogue. There is a ton of funny dialogue with the DLC. I am happy to say the gaming references are still everywhere as you can expect in the series. That being said if you are the type to get annoyed at a lot of notifs and are uninterested with the characters this part may annoy you since it feels like its the most in the series.

+This version has a lot of free DLC so you have a big choice of characters to play throughout the story. On this note, I am again happy to say, you can just keep playing your favorite characters instead of having to grind everyone since this game doesn't have any power creep.

+The big numbers are here. There really isn't a big change in terms of gameplay when compared to rebirth 2 so most of the combat is the same except for the fact that you can focus on going for challenges now too.

+Of course the reason we are in this rabbit hole is the characters. They are all still great, quirky and entertaining with one another. Despite being from a different dimension, the characters are still pretty much the same lovable bunch. This game we have much much much more screentime for Noire so that gets a big plus from me. Of course not to mention the inclusion of Iris Heart. I skip almost all animations in this game's combat but when I use the skill Verbal Abuse from Iris Heart, the l1 button remains unpressed. Neptune and Plutia being the main duo just really makes this game.

+The soundtrack is still amazing as again, it is basically the same as the previous two titles. On the note of sound design, the voice acting is still godlike for both subs and dubs. Iris Heart being voiced by Kana Hanazawa is a godsend and a bonus to the already amazing cast of voice actors this series has.

+Again, there is still fanservice for all.

-Repetitive design for monsters and dungeons makes it a chore to traverse through new dungeons sometimes. It also doesn't help that there's a lot of required quests to progress through the story so you will be going back through these sometimes.

-There is a lot of 4th wall-breaking in the dialogue. This might seem like a plus but god there is actually a metric ton worth of 4th wall-breaking and they really milked it and it got tiring and boring.

-Why are EXE skills locked behind challenges... Specifically the use 100 skills challenge. This was very very frustrating to unlock honestly.

-On the note of unlocking, there are so many plans locked behind Stella's dungeon. I never even reached the break the damage limit plan throughout the game.

-Again like the other installments you will be missing out on stuff and plans if you don't go for new game+

Overall still a really fun game and definitely an upgrade from rebirth 2. Nepnepnep

115938649.review:
[h1]ReBirth3 in 2k22 top NEP?[/h1]
You might not have found out about the Neptunia series before all their good games had already been long released and think about buying an older title for little money. This quick overview aims to tell you if RB3 is the one you should purchase:

[u]Does ReBirth 3 run without issues on a modern rig?[/u]
Well, there are three things to consider here:
1) Idea Factory was being [i]very[/i] unskilled at PC ports back in the day so you have to manually set your wanted resolution and borderless option in the game config files.
2) Even if you chose a high resolution, the game has not by default changeable features such as low quality AA that still make it look pixelated. To combat this you can use a third party mod called "Neptastic" that puts the game visually very close to modded Megadimension VII.
3) The game sadly was coded with a 2GB memory cap and already used to crash every now and then in vanilla. But adding Neptastic will increase this problem immsensely since you now use up more memory. So you will also need to patch the exe of the game to a 4GB limit. Despite that crashes will occur and you need to save often.

[u]Okay, so why should I bother with this mess at all?[/u]
Rebirth3 has several things going for it, that you will not get in any other game produced after it:
- It has by far the largest cast of characters
- It has by far the longest story
- The story is actually somewhat decent and not just a load of Nep Bull
- Countless references to anime and gaming
- It's the last game featuring strategic combat with a guard gaunge on the enemies
- It has a much cleaner interface and menu structure over RB1 and RB2
- Many hidden dungeons
- Countless unlockables and grinds

[u]And where are the cons?[/u]
- Far less dungeon variety than VII
- The presentation aka coolness factor of transforming is more basic
- Stella dungeon is just annoying
- You need to put the time in to unlock stuff like exe drive individually per character
- If you prefered the simple combat structure of VII you might feel annoyed by guard break
- If you prefered the more complex combat structure of Sega Hard girls you might feel annoyed by just saving up SP to exe bosses right away

In any case: Hyperdimension Neptunia Rebirth 3 is the one Nep game that's still worth picking up so many years after its release. And that one already was a remaster of Victory. For the best vintage Nep experience this is the game for you. If on the other hand you prefered the more action oriented better looking 4GO and Ninja Wars releases, better not buy this.

104010227.review:
Re;Birth3 V Generation was probably the most fun Nep game for me to play through multiple NG+ cycles and Platinum. 
For a casual experience, if you're familiar with the other remakes, this is sort of a step up from the features and animations from 1 and 2. The game has a lot to offer, and if you're a fan of these types of games, I would highly recommend a relaxed and fun playthrough. The CG artwork, soundtrack, and voice acting are honestly really good (pretty high tier talent involved) and the story never really gets dull or just an over the top grind. 

In regards to getting 100% achievement, I spent a bit of time trying to set up the routes to the True ending (e.g. getting plans for optional dungeons, finding the materials for Stella's Dungeon Floors, and went through multiple game cycles to get everything in Chapter specific events) and would highly recommend using a guide for a bit of a  more optimized setup. This is down to personal preference, but it's really not worth your time to try and find the intricacies all on your own, especially since the Harem chip is designed to dramatically cut the Lily rank grind down and there's really not much information on how to efficiently utilize it otherwise.

A complaint that I have for this port would be that whenever I am in a dungeon and use a symbol attack or get into a battle, I'm teleported across the map to a fixed spot, or across the entire dungeon when I would be farming a specific enemy for Quests. I read online about it being a Vsync issue or something related to monitor refresh rate with the game, but was not really able to find a viable solution and just had to deal with it. While it didn't really deter me from finishing the plat, it definitely was annoying, and hopefully a fix can be found or better communicated so it doesn't leave a bad impression for newer players (I never had this problem in the other games). 

Ultimately, I would highly recommend this game, as I feel it is the strongest addition to the Re;Verse games and has a lot of content to work with. These games go on sale a lot, and it is honestly worth waiting for the main seasonal sales to buy even if you're on the fence, as it can range to as high as a 90% discount with certain DLCs.

101197227.review:
Rebirth 3 is the first Neptunia game where I would probably recommend playing the previous 2 games before playing this one. Its a game that has a lot of inside jokes and that relies on you understanding the cast quite well. Its fun and builds of the best parts of the previous games to make it way stronger. 

The story is simpler then rebirth 2 but much more consistent in enjoyment. There are some small twists and interesting plot elements that keep the overall plot just as engaging as the usual banter between parties that you should be used to if you played a Neptunia game before.

The combat is simple but a lot more dynamic compare to the previous games, its even more flashy and allows for a lot more customization of party lineups. Out of the first 3 rebirth games I spent the most time here but it honestly didn't really feel all that bad in the end. The animations in combat are really fun and keep the combat engaging even in the late game.

My main complaint would be that the absolute last couple areas require you to grind and even once you grinded and clear everything it seems like they didn't put THAT much effort into the reward for clearing everything in the game. I would have loved to see more effort put into these dungeons. In the end they are absolutely not necessary to enjoy the main bulk of the game and it doesn't get in the way of the main story, but it still sucks to not be rewarded with much after all that work.

In the end its another Neptunia game but I would honestly say this is the best out of the Rebirth trilogy. Its much more engaging and still keeps all the things that give Neptunia all the personality that fans of the series love.

100521966.review:
My first Neptunia game (I watched others play the first two on YouTube) and I'm glad it was.
 
1. Critics often describe gameplay is a severe drawback to this franchise, and while I can't speak for the other two games, I did not feel that to be the case in this game. The attack styles and skills had enough variety that I felt as though my strategy decisions were meaningful. It's nothing revolutionary but it will not impact your enjoyment of the game. My only complaint is that most of the dungeons feel a bit lacking in terms of utility after the post-game, and only one or two are worth grinding in.

2. In general, the story is fine, taking on a more light-hearted tone compared to its predecessor. The bread and butter of Neptunia is putting the cast into a room together and watching them interact in goofy ways so it gets the job done. Speaking of the cast...

3. Plutia is adorable. I love everything about her character, from her soft and fluffy design, to her bubbly (and slightly sadistic) personality, to her absurd attack style. Even her snail-like speech cadence is great as it means I get to listen to her speak just a bit longer. I think Neptunia would really benefit from adding more characters with unusual weapon choices because seeing her fight bosses using semi-animated dolls in her pajamas brings a smile to my face every time I see it. PLEASE bring her back in another mainline game and not retcon her from existence like she was in VII :')

10/10 would take naps with Plutia again. Oh, and the game's good too I guess.

93706271.review:
Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth 3 (aka Victory) is probably the best overall Neptunia game, with the best cast, best story and humor, as well as very smooth gameplay with great quality-of-life features.

Re;Birth 3 is mostly a straight port of Hyperdimension Neptunia Victory which was originally released in 2012 on the PS3 and was a resounding success that put the Neptunia series and Idea Factory on the map. The formula proved to be so succesful that Victory's engine and systems were used for the Re;Birth remakes of the first two Neptunia games, as well as the base for [url=store.steampowered.com/app/524580]Fairy Fencer[/url].

In this adventure Neptune travels to another dimension called the Ultra Dimension, where she meets another Planeptune CPU called Plutia as well as all new and redesigned versions of Noire, Blanc and Vert. The star of the show is of course Plutia, she's based on Sega Megadrive and is a bipolar sleepy head with a very special transformation gimmick. She acts as a second protagonist and stays with you for the whole game. Together with Neptune they have excellent synergy and their stunts and antics are lots of fun. The game's story is also pretty clever and covers a very long period of gaming history, from the Atari video game crash to the release of the first Xbox console, hence the different designs for Noire, Blanc and Vert, as they're supposed to be retro versions of their usual selves. There's a pretty large cast of awesome villains and some other CPU's will also be joining the fray as the story develops further.

The gameplay is the smoothest in the series. It's neither too hard nor too easy, and you never need to grind. Material gathering has been streamlined with a better version of the Stella's Dungeon mini-game (first featured in Re;Birth 2). There's no need to grind shares or lily ranks to unlock any content. The only possibly questionable change is the removal of the EXE gauge, you now use SP for EXE drives and everyone has 1000 SP which can be replenished via either rush attacks or consumables. Returning to world map doesn't restore SP.

The game is quite long at 50+ hours. There are 3 endings (bad, normal, true), and reaching the true ending unlocks a lengthy post-game chapter with its own story and events. Almost all of the characters in the series are playable, one way or another.

To sum it up, whether you're a newcomer or an old fan, Re;Birth 3 is a must play if you have any interest in Neptunia or Idea Factory games in general. You can even play it as your first Neptunia game, as Re;Birth 1 is non-canon and there's only a few references to Re;Birth 2.

90201814.review:
Re;Birth 3 is a return to form after the disappointing Re;Birth 2, but still fails to live up to Re;Birth 1. While the writing itself back to being amusing and irreverent, 70% of the entire game's main story is filler, and conversations go on for so, so long, with often little purpose. You will be fighting each of this game's villain group, the Seven Sages, 3-4 times each, even to the frustration of the characters themselves. This, of course, is not the first time that Neptunia has recycled villains, but it is the first time that you win each fight, for the character to simply be let go and perpetrate a new Saturday-morning-villain-esque plan. It's boring and does nothing to progress the plot or facilitate character growth--it's just fluff.

As with any Neptunia game, you need to go into this game expecting a visual novel with RPG elements, there's 'that' much. Yes, the gameplay itself is designed to be classic JRPG grind and played through multiple times, but after the first run you will be shocked at how quickly the game flies by when you're skipping the copious dialogue. That in mind, the gameplay is the same as ever, though extra attention has been given to the pacing of skills, items and plans in this game, making it feel a lot more thought out and less game-breaking. Still, if you're familiar with the Neptunia format then you will be falling right back into that same groove, with all the same enemy types and maps, so don't burn yourself out if you've just finished Re;Birth 2.

Re;Birth 3 lacks the strong story arc and supporting characters that Re1 had, focusing almost exclusively on the new main character, Plutia, and the CPUs interactions with the new villains. There is no main goal of the story, and the CPUs just kinda faff around, responding to things as they happen, leading to zero urgency and the characters themselves calling certain (critical path) events a waste of time or side-story. If you like the Neptunia format and writing, it's more of the same, and will satiate you in the same way an anime series' movie will give you a taste of what you loved, but ultimately leave you wanting more and craving the original. That said, Plutia and Peachy are instant favourites and welcome additions to the cast, and elevate the game from being pure fan-fiction, but I could do with less sexual assault.

Speaking of which, adding Peachy and Plutia to Re;Birth 1 as DLC was kinda a massive spoiler for this game's story, so... that's a shame.

76736204.review:
This game is about Neptune moving out of home and forming a family.

This game is just funny, there's barely anything in it that isn't made a joke. The villains are ridiculous, the characters are as always fun, the other dimension premise is just that and you can't expect a serious story when one of your mains is Iris Heart. People say this game is really mean towards Nepgear but it does it as an actual joke, it doesn't just s*** on the character. Honestly i ended up liking Nepgear a lot more in this game than i ever did in the previous one. I think the problem was that while RB2 focused on Nepgear, RB1 and 3 follow Neptune around but their stories don't really focus just on her.

Combat changed a bit, but not really that much. I found it a bit too easy (it's the third game with the same mechanics after all) so i used Fortify Enemies from the start, that made it pretty hard at times but fun (if you enjoy that kind of thing).

The localization of this game is terrible, just awful. There's a very easy to apply patch for that that improves it a lot (if you like MEMEptune then keep it as it is).
As always the japanese voice acting is great and covers almost everything (even the dlc characters events), the english voices are VERY limited in this one.

The game is a bit noisy, the character's footsteps sound like buckets instead of shoes and the constant jingle every time you get a character achievement is a bit too much.

One thing i kind of disliked was the lack of playable characters relevant to the story. Although there's a lot of DLC characters (known faces if you played the other RB games) and they even get their own small character scenes and events.

Great mechanics and love the new characters; Plutia is kickass in both forms though the dirty-ness is a bit too heavy handed at times.

But generally, it's still a good game to laugh at and to laugh with when you need a break from all those dark-gritty games in your library. Sometimes you just need bright colours and loud, squeaky voices.

Shame on there only being 3 endings though too; I expected a shares grind but there wasn't one, so the shares bar seemed a little redundant.

Did I enjoy the game? Hell yeah. Will I play it again? Not too sure...

This is my favourite of the rebirth trilogy and is a solid JRPG overall, it's also the longest of the trilogy with a first playthrough (provided you read everything that's available) will run you about 30 hours. If you've played rebirth 2 then the gameplay is very similar, it's average but unique and is overall solid. In typical Nep fashion though the dialogue is why you want to play this game, and it's one of the funniest in the series imo.

It also comes with a bunch of free DLC which is great and is actually pretty challenging because unlike previous titles you don't get access to the high end colosseum fights until right near the end of the game and the equipment they give you. There is a lot to do in this game, especially the post game stuff after the true ending, and the bonus fights are much easier than previous entries because they don't block your skills and items, be warned the strongest boss in the game is in one of the post game stories and even at level 999 is quite hard. My playtime is how long it took to get all achievements and do everything, it will take you less depending on what you want to do.

If you're a fan of Nep games or looking for a JRPG that doesn't take itself seriously and provides a nice change compared to all the serious titles out there I'd recommend this title. It also goes on sale quite a lot so you can pick it up for cheap.

71651926.review:
Honestly...compared to the original game on the PS3 - Hyperdimension Neptunia Victory - I consider Re;Birth3 to be a step backwards. I'm truly not a big fan of Re;Birth3, despite how much it actually attempts to remix and improve upon what Victory did bad.

[h1]Here are areas where Re;Birth3 improves upon Victory:[/h1]
- Reduced difficulty.
Victory was sort of infamous for being insanely tough and very grindy. I've counted many times on Victory where I was thrown into a boss battle, only to realize I was incredibly under-leveled and underprepared for it. A perfect example would be the first Blanc boss battle where I had to grind nearly 15 levels to actually stand a chance against her. Re;Birth3 solves this problem by not only reducing the difficulty overall, but also by essentially shoving overpowered characters into your party that make grinding pretty much a non-issue.
- Additional story content.
Re;Birth3 attempts to remix the story from Victory by adding additional supplementary material. You get to experience it as soon as you start the game as you are thrown into a VR-esque world as Neptune and navigate a mini-dungeon to escape it. Stuff like that is peppered throughout the game and it's a welcome addition.
- More maker characters.
Victory as a whole was only played with CPU characters. IF and Compa were not playable and it didn't have any other maker characters, at least not without DLC to my understanding. Re;Birth3 solves that problem by giving you more maker characters to use in battle and actually incorporates them into the story without drastically altering everything.
- Framerate.
Victory on PS3 is also infamous for running like absolute crap. The game can't even hold a steady 30 FPS most of the time and dips into the teens very frequently. For some - that makes the game absolutely unplayable and I can understand that. Thankfully, Re;Birth3 solves that issue with a silky smooth, uncapped framerate, or you can choose to manually cap it to 60 with VSync or something.

[h1]Here are areas where Re;Birth3 falls short compared to Victory:[/h1]
- The PC port.
I had a lot of trouble with the PC port of Re;Birth3 in particular. From random softlocks, game crashes, black screens, etc., it was genuinely frustrating at times to deal with this poor port of the game. There are tons of community made patches for these issues, but unless you know where to look - the experience out of the box is not going to be a pleasant one.
- The gameplay.
Re;Birth1 and Re;Birth2 were heavily based upon Victory's gameplay. Heck, I'd argue those games are just reskins of Victory slapped onto Steam, which wouldn't exactly be inaccurate, but those games are superior because Victory's gameplay formula [b]works.[/b] Re;Birth3 attempts to mix things up from the other Re;Birth games by changing one small yet crucial mechanic - [b]the EXE drive.[/b] Short and to the point - it's annoying and cumbersome in this game, making it way less useful than it was in the previous games.
- No scouting system.
The scouting system in the original, while a bit annoying since it was required for the True Ending, was overall a fun side-mechanic to unlock optional dungeons you can use for grinding or getting useful items early on if you get lucky. That system is gone from Re;Birth3 and instead replaced with the much slower, much less useful Stella's Dungeon mechanic.

I'm sorry to say but I don't really recommend Re;Birth3. The additions and improvements are nice and all, but with a crappy PC port, inferior gameplay due to the gimped EXE system and the removal of the scouting system makes me prefer the original version of the game by a longshot. It sucks too because I think that Victory's story, despite being incredibly long and the cutscenes feeling like they take 60 years to complete, is the best in the series, considering it's the perfect chance to get to know a set of CPUs from a different dimension right down from their humble beginnings.

Victory/Re;Birth3 takes place in what's canonically known as the Ultradimension, and you begin the game in a very primitive version of Gamindustri with 2 nations, eventually expanding into 5 as you go on through the game. You get to see each CPU's humble beginnings and how they deal with hardships running their nations and all that stuff - it goes through a very Neptunia-esque story about competition, co-operation and then defeating some bigger villain in the picture. In Victory/Re;Birth3 - you get to experience every waking [i]moment[/i] and, to me - that makes the story engaging and a lot more personal. I seriously prefer the Ultradimension CPUs to the Hyperdimension ones.

It's just a shame that Re;Birth3 is just not very good in my opinion. If you have a PS3 and don't mind the flaws I pointed out about Victory here - that version is the one you should get, should you want to experience it. But if you don't and are considering Re;Birth3 - at least consider looking into fixing the awful PC port yourself via community patches so the game doesn't freeze or softlock constantly for you.

And for the third game the same goes: I played all 3 Re;Birth games back to back and I loved it.

Like the first and the second this is partly a dungeon crawler with turn-based battles and partly a visual novel. It's a parody on gaming as it is and it knows it. The fourth wall is breached several times.
Again the humor and the characters are lovely. I really, really like Plutia and her alter ego, that brought a whole different dynamic to the group. 
Again the battles weren't complicated and the pacing was relatively good. In the same fashion as the first game, the bosses had some different difficulty compared to the regular enemies. Again a bit a grindy game, though like the second this one suffered less from it than the first.

If you like games that aren't all that serious, with a decent pacing, ok battles and don't have issue with half a game being a VN, then this too certainly is something to play.

The only other complaint is the massive amount of grinding needed for money for end-game weapons and stupidly high cost of clothes and accessories. 57726030.review:
Putting it against the other Nep games i've played, which is almost all of them, I can say that I hate this one. 
The story started out decent but oh boy does it drag on to the point of me losing complete interest in everyone and everything. A massive portion of the humour in this game delves down to "lmao boobs", there was boob jokes in the previous titles but not to the extent that there is in this game, it's just ridiculous. I mean, that's all Vert's character is in this game "I have the boob, oh smeg she has the bigger boob REEEEEEeeEEEEEeeee" and I hate it. SPeaking of the characters, I fuckin hate Plutie, dunno what it is but I just canna stand her, she pisses me off to no extent, one of the main reasons I dunna like this title. Actually, I felt like all the characters got a massive downgrade character wise in this one, everyone just felt wrong and off and like they were trying too hard to be what they were in the previous titles but just weren't (And yes I know "hurr durr they're the counterparts from another dimension, they're not the same", but I don't give a fuck, they're worse than they wore before, even Nep felt wrong).

Onto actual gameplay, they fucked the combat I feel. Yeah it's the exact same combat system as Rebirth 1 and 2, but the removal of the EXE bar and having absolutely everything tied to SP was a dumbass desicion I think. SP is static, you can't increase your total amount, it's always 1000, which makes the fact that every special move, the exe moves, and even the combo finishes depend on your SP dumb. Beacuse exe and finishers are tied to it, I felt like that if I used special moves in combat I was being penizlised because I couldn't maximise my damage outside of them because the rest of the time i'd be farming SP with weaker moves just to do decent damage, spent most of the time ignoring the specials because of it and only using EXE attacks to finish fights off. 

I liked the addition of the character challenges and was happy to see them come back in Mega Nep V II, which i've yet to finish but am already enjoying it a shit load more than this one. But that's about it for enjoyment, didn't really like the "new" characters, the story, or the combat changes. Did the game twice, once for the normal ending and then again for the true ending because the normal ending was so bad that it made me angry so I had to go through again to be less mad. 

Oh and also Nepgear gets absolutely shafted in this game, and being a Nepgear fan this also jades my view on the game. 

So my main reasons for disliking the game are Plutie being awful, and Nepgear getting skuffed. but I don't give a fuck I don't like the game, worst in the series.

[h1]This is a [b]NEUTRAL[/b] review[/h1]

[b]Some good things[/b]

The new SP/EXE system, but I'll get into deeper info on this little bit later

Japanese audio is well voiced/acted especially Plutia, Nepgear, Neptune, and Peashy. Main story is 100% voiced, and some on-and-off for other dialogue scenarios.

Couple of new characters, or remodels, maybe....

Lots of playable characters

Lots of events/dialogues, about 2-10 minute long .-.

New/Better Stella system.

New dungeons, some from previous games

Few new bosses

Better 2D character models

Hours, and hours of content/story.

Replayability

The grind, it's not too boring.



[b]Things that made me feel that the game isn't worth[/b]

Previous games, Re;birth 1 and 2 had the same SP/Exe gauge system and was pretty easy to use, like very easy. But things change a whole lot in Re;birth 3, with a whole new Sp/Exe gauge system, they're combined into one, meaning you build your SP as your exe gauge, which is also used (but not consumed) to do EX finish and to do EXE drive (consumed x/4, x=amount of bars required) and lastly, transformations/SP skills use up your SP, and every character has 1,000 SP which they build up their own, no shared gauge like the two previous games. Building up your own SP takes a REALLY long time unless you could rack up huge combos/rush combos

Constant crashing on dialogues, it's not too frequent but it happens quiet often, more than the previous 2 games.

Reused content, lol, same enemies from the previous 2 games.

Dialogue scenes appear to be laggy? I don't know much about game design/programming but 
a rendering still 2D background image isn't supposed to be that rough right?

MAGES. dialogues seem to drop and raise in volume for some reason?

Dialogues are super long making me just skim or skip through it entirely, there's A LOT of it.

The antagonists get on my nerves, which is a good thing for the game I guess?

49749273.review:
[h1] Wonderful Fun for Turn-Based RPG Fans [/h1]

I will update this review when I have more time logged onto it. But I just got done playing Megadimension Victory II and booting up Cyberdimension 4 Goddesses Online. Those games are very sad compared to this game. This game is an example of why the Neptunia series has so many fans. IFI...please return to making great games like this.

[b] The Good Points [/b]

1) You get a plan to make a weapon. It tells you what you need to farm to get what you need. You go farm, you build the plan, and you buy the weapon. It's beautiful and simple.

2) The story flows naturally instead of completely depending on the "converse" option of MDVII.

3) The sound is sharp and the graphics are crisp. This game is not a shabby port. It is a work of art.

4) You can play with the team you want to play with without worrying about grinding for 10 hours in the same dungeon just to catch up the party members that were left behind due to all the party member swapping that is mandatory in MDVII.

5) Turning on and off world plans using system memory is genius for a game built on the idea of gaming world. If you don't want the EXP booster you got from the DLC, turn it off in game! It's user friendly, lore-friendly, and freaking AWESOME! How about some of that user-friendliness in MDVII?

6) This is very minor, but...I LOVE the "battle complete" fan fare music in the Hyperdimension games. It is missing from MDVII. I want it back.

7) Quests happen when they are supposed to...unlike how they get dumped into the bucket in MDVII. If you get a quest in a Hyperdimension game, you can go do it right then (or soon after). If you get a quest in MDVII, you may not be able to do it for 30 more game hours (no joke).


[b] The Bad Points [/b]

1) To afford a single costume you must get the most valuable coliseum award in the game three times. This is just nuts. I would have LOVED to have been able to buy the costumes via DLC.

2) I couldn't turn in a quest because I didn't know that the boss event I was staring at would make the quest I just completed expire. But it wasn't necessary that I hand in the quest, so it's no big deal. And now that I know that this sort of thing happens, I can work to prevent it in the future.

3) The A and B buttons seems to be transposed. As a result, I occasionally cancel my attack when I mean to use a guard break attack. Again, it's no big deal.

4) There is no new game plus. There is no way to play the whole game through with your favorite waifu team in their favorite duds...even if you do all that insane work to get the costumes.

49154122.review:
For those with crashing or rendering problems:

I've played the game for 10+ hours, crashing 3 times in the middle with a long section of game progress lost(pew...). Since I didn't have problems with rb1 and rb2, I checked the problems and found that there's a OpenGL driver in the steam installation. I have Intel Core Graphics GPU, and the file was ig75icd32.dll. 

With `dumpbin -exports`, I found that the function exports in the dll was exactly the same as ig8icd32.dll in system directory (sysWOW64 for x64 archetecture's x86 dlls).

It is highly likely that steam's driver conflicts with the driver installed on the system, and the game may crash because of a conflicting function call. I removed the steam dll from the game directory, and the game runs as if nothing has happened. Currently I can't safely say that the crashing problem is solved (still need more time to see), but this solution did not bring about new problems as far as I've learned.

Other vendors' driver may also have similar problems, and manually changing them may or may not solve the problem.

(DLL Hell again...)

In all, the game is a great game. Nepu!


游戏有闪退等问题的可以看过来

之前完了十几个小时，闪退了三次，还掉了一个好长的进度。。。后来检查了一下，发现steam安装的文件中存在OpenGL显卡驱动文件。我的intel核显是ig75icd32.dll。 dumpbin -exports，发现函数导出和系统目录下的ig8icd32.dll完全相同（64位系统32位文件在sysWOW64目录）。

很可能是steam和系统安装的驱动冲突导致函数调用发生错误。实测将steam的 ig75icd32.dll 移开后游戏基础运行不受影响，闪退是否修复因时间原因还未完全确认。

其他品牌的显卡驱动可能也会存在。如果发生闪退或者显示等问题，可以考虑尝试手动解决冲突问题。

（DLL Hell真可怕。。。）

48132532.review:
For those who are TL;DR, I'm going to start by saying that Re;Birth3 is an explosive game.

Now, let me explain.

The game begins fairly slow, giving the basics of any Re;Birth game, average tutorial stuff.  Then, the game's main plot begins, and man, is it a blast.  There's several new characters and several jokes that are actually quite creative.

The wave of enjoyment continues, but after a few chapters, I began to notice a pattern.  There was a lot, and I mean a [i]ton[/i] of side dialogue.  This is usally a great thing in games, but it drastically distracted from the JRPG elements of the game.  Most of the hours I have in this game aren't gameplay hours, but rather time spent reading a ton of side conversations.

When you [i]do[/i] play the game though, it's quite enjoyable.  There's a few minor improvements to the systems, including Stella's Dungeon and a 'passive' stat gain.  Some characters seem overly weak compared to others, but much of this is due to bundled DLCs.

Overall, this is a pretty good Re;Birth game.  I enjoyed it a fair amount, and the endings were alright.  [spoiler] Good ending feels a bit rushed, but that doesn't really matter tbh. [/spoiler]  I can tell that it's a lot more of a visual novel than its predecessors, but is still quite enjoyable.

44801342.review:
The endless pointless dialogue in this game makes Seinfeld, the supposed show "about nothing," look like Plato's Republic. All the characters ever do is make a few game references, compare breast sizes, or whine about having to do any work while your stereotypical serious character scolds them for being lazy. Then proceed to milk the "joke," the "comedy," if you will, for endless hours on end. Or at least feels like hours to me because of inane the dialogue really is.

Like seriously...there IS a story to this game, but I'm not quite sure what it is because my attention span just goes right out the window when the characters needlessly and endlessly prattle on about being geeky gamers and making fun of each other in the most unclever and childish ways possible. I THINK the story is supposed to have a bit of political intrigue?

There are several lands run by CPUs/ie the main waifus who are supposed to represent different real life gaming consoles (though I don't see how other than the colour scheme of their clothes...err...kind of?) and there's a group of generic villains called the Seven Sages who want to NOT have CPUs rule the lands, but also want to enforce better rules for each land. Some of citizens actually agree with their ideas on how to organize society, and then...I dunno? That's kind of mentioned for like...a second before the characters proceed to just insult each other endlessly and needlessly as I already mentioned.

But yeah...the gameplay is good, though. It's nothing revolutionary, but it is actually fun to play its battle system where you can assign different combo attacks per character. I think it's a decent system to focus on breaking the enemy's guard before spamming heavy attacks or using rush attacks to build up our combo number for...I forget what that contributes to.

Anyway! As you can tell my thoughts and opinions on this game are kind of scattered and poorly written. Such is the effect of having to put up with the most inane and meaningless dialogue of any game, book, TV show, or movie I have ever experienced in my life. If the developers could hire an editor to help cut down some of the excess dialogue so that we actually get a good balance between comedy and story progression that would be greeaaaaat. But as it stands now, the comedy lands for only a short chuckle until you are forced to put up with milked out and watered down versions of the original joke while the characters proceed to prattle on and on and on and on and on and on and on...

Lots of grinding and farming, areas and fighting, its like Sword Art Online and I saw another Neptunia game that has this style so I am hyped when I get enough money!

Gameplay
Lots of Dialogue and I love a story that gives you every bit of detail. I just hate that every event, even if its small, has a long dialouge with it, I still feel like I am not seeing something.
Lots of Area's to explore and fight as you get to use special abilites and see how great the animation is!
Voice acting is great
The Graphics at its highest are nice, not perfect but nice!

My Conclusion
I still need to play other games to see if I can get more of the story but it feels like I wasted it on the 'final' rebirth game so I may not even try and bother to get the other ones. Other than that it was really fun, nice game play, lovable characters, loonnggg dialogue, and such throwbacks to other games!

Should you buy it?
Yes!
At full price?
Unless you hate lots of dialogue and long 'grinding for exp'  then heck yes!

44657276.review:
Al igual que en mi [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/eltitodan/recommended/351710/]anterior reseña[/url], ofreceré mi punto de vista sobre los cambios que ha sufrido este [i]remake[/i] respecto a sus dos predecesores en vez de evaluarlo en su totalidad, dadas sus grandes similitudes. Para quien no haya probado aún la saga [i]Neptunia[/i], recomiendo leerse [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/eltitodan/recommended/282900/]este análisis[/url] en su lugar.[list]
[*]Hay una gran alteración en una de las mecánicas clave de las batallas: las habilidades SP y los EXE Drive. Ahora ambos comparten una misma barra recargable independiente para cada personaje, haciendo más difícil el [i]spam[/i] de estos últimos. Me parece un buen soplo de aire fresco respecto al sistema anterior.
[*]La historia continúa justo por donde se quedó [i]Re;Birth2[/i] en vez de liarnos con otro universo desconectado de los demás. Casi todos los eventos se dan en una nueva dimensión introducida en esta entrega, la cual estará conectada a la anterior en la trama. Tiene 3 posibles desenlaces, y considero todos ellos válidos, a diferencia de los 9 del juego anterior. Por lo general, me ha gustado más que la de la entrega previa, y los personajes nuevos me han parecido bastante interesantes.
[*]La tercera parte de la saga viene con todos los DLCs excepto uno preinstalados con el juego base, algo que extiende bastante su duración y contenido. No comprendo qué llevó a Idea Factory a regalarlos de esa forma, pero ya sabes lo que dicen: a caballo regalado, no le mires el diente.
[*]He notado una bajada significante en la dificultad respecto a las entregas anteriores. Sin embargo, esto se puede arreglar fácilmente con el plan "fortalecer enemigos", el cual he estado usando durante casi todo el juego.
[*]Lamentablemente, IF demuestra una vez más ser una empresa de reciclaje. Esta parte vuelve a pecar de imperfecciones arregladas en la anterior; se reutilizan demasiadas mazmorras tanto del primer juego como del segundo, "compensando", en cierto modo, con un par de escenarios nuevos con diseños remarcablemente atractivos. Además, gran parte de los eventos importantes en la historia vuelven a carecer de voces dobladas, un detalle prácticamente imperceptible en [i]Re;Birth2[/i].
[*]El HUD, tanto en las batallas como en los menús, ha sufrido una renovación estética casi por completo. Prácticamente todos los cambios me parecen agradables a la vista, y en mi opinión no causan ningún estorbo innecesario.
[*]Por alguna razón, este juego me ha dado incontables bugs y crasheos, y los personajes solían quedarse atascados en el suelo cuando presionaba el botón de saltar mientras estaba en una mazmorra. No he tenido estos problemas con las otras dos entregas, así que esto es definitivamente un cambio para mal. Aquí hay algunos ejemplos de dichos errores:
- https://steamuserimages-a.akamaihd.net/ugc/942829922916007065/E7223023CA451B820162D9883BA923F5C186A768/
- https://steamuserimages-a.akamaihd.net/ugc/941705094009948427/4733B4EC2F88305CC95A4B287847F13861AF2983/
- https://steamuserimages-a.akamaihd.net/ugc/945082038043015422/D99BE9B51BE0E3E018F2E3BAA7284F7A81115B80/
[*]Reaparece el minijuego [i]Stella's ☆ Dungeon[/i]. Sigo pensando que es [i]pay-to-win[/i] gracias al único DLC no incluido en este juego, y de hecho tiene más impacto en la jugabilidad que en [i]Re;Birth2[/i]. No obstante, ha sido mejorado tanto estéticamente como en sus mecánicas, y ahora se puede completar en una cantidad aceptable de tiempo. Por tanto, ahora lo considero un buen añadido al juego.[/list]
Me agrada decir que toda la trilogía me parece recomendable [strike]si eres parte de ese grupo demográfico tan [i]niche[/i] al que esta franquicia está claramente enfocada[/strike] si te apetece olvidarte de todo con un juego entretenido y una historia carente de toda seriedad. La saga [i]Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth[/i] me ha dado muy buenos momentos y, a pesar de sus evidentes imperfecciones, permanecerá conmigo durante mucho tiempo.

43865924.review:
After the second Neptunia game had not been as enjoyable for me as its predecessor, I came into Neptunia 3 cautious and hoping that this game would bring the funny back. Thankfully, the devs appear to have thought the same way because Neptunia 3, or "V Generation", is a welcome return to the sort of game that I enjoyed so much with the first installment with its mix of comedy and fourth-wall breaking. And having the characters talk about the size of their boobs.

A few years after the second game, the land of Gamindustri is back to relative normality with the CPU's on good terms and running their nations. Except for Neptune, of course, who is far too busy playing tons of games to do any actual work - much to the annoyance of the oracle Histoire and her younger sister Nepgear. But after being forced to get out of her home and do some quests, Neptune suddenly finds herself getting sucked into a portal and falling (again) into an alternate dimension. But when I say Alternate dimension, it actually is also something of a return to the past as the only nations that exist in this other world are Planeptune (Sega) and Lowee (Nintendo). In other words, Neptune has entered a world reminicent of the older "console wars" of the late 1980's and early 1990's. So Neptune, over the course of years of trying to figure out how to return to her dimension and screwing around, gets to witness the evolution of Gamindustri from the late 1980's to around the mid 2000's. And for the cast to compare boob sizes with the other characters and CPU's.

This was actually rather interesting to me seeing what this game portrayed and then to try to compare it to my sketchy knowledge of how things went in real life. I didn't get all of the references or what everything was meant to represent, but I got enough to understand and enjoy the story. Planeptune comes off as a nation that somehow survives against all odds despite its CPU's being extremely lazy and not doing their job. Lowee is the ancient nation with a traditional Japanese look, but which hampers itself by being closed off to the outside and lacking innovation. Lastation enters the fray and quickly surpasses both of its rivals due to being driven by innovation and seeking constant improvement. Leanbox jumps into the game after watching from the sidelines for a while, but ends up having far more bark than bite and doesn't make much of an initial impact. Lastly, there is a "PC Continent" in one of the DLC packs which is a gated land reserved only for those over 18 and is implied to be a haven for [i]massive[/i] amounts of porn. If that last one didn't tip you off, then i'll say now that the Gamindustri that Neptunia 3 depicts appears to be the Japanese gaming market rather than the global one. At least that's how it came off to me. Either way, you get to go to all of these places as Neptune throughout the course of the game and enjoy the stories that unfold. And to watch characters try to come up with ways to make their boobs grow bigger.

Character-wise, there are two major additions aside from the cast of villains: Plutia and Peashy. Both of these characters were DLC party members in the first game, and if you read my review of it you will know that Plutia in particular was a very powerful party member with a bizzare character transformation. This time, Plutia and Peashy are actual characters that you get to spend quite alot of time with as part of the main plot. Plutia, who is the alternate dimension CPU of Planeptune, is a sleepy stuffed animal-making girl that comes off as a massive airhead. But when she transforms she ends up becoming a psycho dominatrix who speaks in innuendos, terrifies everyone she meets, and inflicts severe trauma upon numerous characters. Compared to this, Peashy is rather dull by being little more than a super-strong little kid who floats between cute and annoying. And as a topic of annoyance for the other characters because Peashy has the largest boobs in the entire cast when she transforms.

Regarding the villains, the piracy allegory that annoyed me so much in Neptunia 2 appears to be gone entirely in favor of... something else. To be perfectly honest, I'm not entirely sure what they were all meant to represent. One of them, Rei Ryghts, is spelled out quite clearly, but it is more murky for the others. The impression I ended up coming up with was that they were supposed to represent moral guardian types who wanted to completely fuck up Gamindustri. But unlike the Piracy issue where I consider it to be a fight between two dark greys rather than the black and white Neptunia 2 portrayed it as, this is far less ambiguous. Moral guardians are just shitheads, so I had absolutely no problem with them being depicted as such. It certainly gave me extra motivation to beat them up when their boss battles came up. And to watch their secret meetings where they didn't talk about boobs.

As for the gameplay, it is pretty much the same as it has been for previous Neptunia games. The same JRPG stuff. The same cloned repetitive dungeons. The same need to grind levels to fight tougher enemies. And so on. The biggest change is the SP/EXE bar which now is limited to 1,000 for all characters. This is rather annoying since it means that the best moves can't be used much at all and you have to do a fair number of regular attacks to recharge it. Little problem against trash monsters in the dungeons. A bit more of a problem against harder boss fights. Also thanks to DLC, Stella's Dungeon now takes far less time to explore and so has become less annoying. Once you get the best equipment, it really does become a quick and easy way to get a bunch of items. And it is something you will probably want to check to see if it is finished after having gone through lengthy scenes where a fight nearly starts over the importance of boob size.

Neptunia 3 brought the series back to the more comedic tone found in the first game, but which took a backseat in the second. The story was surprisingly enjoyable as a journey through the history of game consoles. The characters are as good as they always have been in this series, with Plutia being a particularly fun addition to the cast. Gameplay is still a JRPG slog, but it is made much easier with the bonus "Plans" you can get that boost XP gain and such. After having been so annoyed by Neptunia 2's piracy allegory that I gave it a "no" recommendation for ruining my fun, this was a welcome return to what I had enjoyed about the first Neptunia game. Actually, Neptunia 3 is probably my favorite game in the series so far. An easy "yes" from me. With only one more game left in the "main" story to play (for now), I do wonder how this will all wrap up. Hopefully it will end on a high note.

By the way, this game has alot of dialogue about boobs. I'm not sure if I mentioned that already.

42712125.review:
The best of the Re;Birth franchise IMO. The story is so ridiculous, the villains in the game are equally ridiculous. Plutia is hilarious, I don't really like the yandere concept much but this game used it in such a way that it's impossible not to laugh at how ridiculous it is.

Stella's Dungeon is great in this game. A wonderful way to earn items for making plans without having to do so much grinding. It doesn't stop you from needing to grind but it definitely helps ease the pain of the previous games. Also Stella requires much less micro management if you spend $0.99 for the DLC to get that ability that lets her return with the items if she's defeated, you can just send her to attempt to clear a whole dungeon.

This game is the most ridiculous of the Re;Birth games in story telling. I don't mean that in a bad way. The villains are hilarious, the main characters are hilarious, Sadie is hilarious (Plutia), I mean they really went all out pushing the humor card in this game and I appreciated it a lot. 

You should definitely play Re;Birth 1 and 2 before this one so you can prepare yourself mentally for how utterly hilarious the story telling is lol.

On top of all that, there's a "post game" that gives you a little side story to do after you beat the game unrelated to the main story and the concept of that side story is hilarious. If you're a real gamer you will know exactly what I mean when you see it lol.

So much content packed into this game. If I had to give it 1 complaint though, I feel like they didn't voice act enough of the lines which is a shame. I really love the dub voicing in this game although I am probably alone with this feeling.

I loved this game the most out of all the Re;Birth games. I'm still trying to grind levels to finish up post game :P
