41958969.review:
Hyperdimension Rebirth 3 is the best Neptunia game released, although I would encourage playing all previous games prior to this, as they split the cast in half and have varying tonal shifts in comparison to one another, especially with Rebirth 2.

Pro's:

-The voice acting in these games (in English anyway) is top notch and the voice actors clearly show there love for there characters and want you to like each of the characters in there own way. Prime examples would be those who voice Nepgear (Purple Sister), who generally has a cute yet concerned voice so that story can be coherently be told to the player with out much consideration on character perspectives twisting anything. (Imagining Neptune rather than Nepgear commentating on the current state of the story and how.... o wait.) Another example of voice acting would be that of both Noire and AnnoyDeath (A villian), who perfectly harmonize in there over the top performance and complement on another so well, which makes for some hillarious scenes between the two. You can see for yourself on Youtube of the scene from the anime between to the two if you are undecided on whether to buy the game or not.

-The most colourful and interesting cast to choose from to date, introducing all of the playable characters from Rebirth 1 and 2, whilst also introducing further characters to play around with. With there being a wide arrange of characters to play overall, the game also allows you to play in whatever play style you want to, with a variety of balances between offence and defence, as well as combinations that allow you to really break the damage cap, the options are endless.

-The difficulty for the game is tailored entirely on how you want to approach the game, with there being so many characters to choose from, as well as a difficulty selection screen that can determine the strength of the enemies that you face, without any effect on the story for those choices inparticular.

-The characters interactions, just like any Neptunia game is a  beautiful, 4th wall breaking, otaku inspired work of art, that only certain individuals will be able to fully appreciate. The cast, with the introduction with alternatives to the exsisting characters Vert (Green Heart), Noire (Black Heart) and Blanc (White Heart), allowing for differing situations that involve them in different scenarios, as well as entirely new characters like Plutia (Iris Heart), this overall makes the game feel like much more of an extension to the already adorable cast of characters.

-Speaking of characters, the Seven Sages was a more creative way of drawing out the situation that each character was placed in from the persepctive of both casts of characters relative to one another, with a few suprises here and there to keep it interesting. By this I mean that unlike the other game's, the villians have there own objectives and instead of being plain underlings like clearly shown in Rebirth 2. The main villian certainly being someone who does some pretty terrible things in order to complete there objective and which is certainly a quest in order to save her rather than to simply defeat her. 

-In my opinion the more colourful and enjoyable to look at game in the series, especially with the menu screen, that makes full use of the screen space and anime character sprites. Same can be said for the in game world, models and particles. Generally full of vibrant colours to make each seen feel surreal and more fantasy like.

-Although mobs and levels are generally recycled from previous games, it allows you to famialrise yourself with the environments so that you always generally know which direction you should be going in. Even some of the old bosses are reintroduced into the series which are always welcome and some new levels are added into the mix that spice up the experience. Inparticular the new Lowee castle level is suprisingly high in quality in comparison to everything else as well as the last level having a generally awesome looking colour scheme to take screenshots with if desired.

Con's:

-The main issue that I have with this tittle is the consistency in which the game can crash, due to there being issues with loading textures that cause the game to bug out or even sometimes with the menuing malfunctioning and casuing your game to essentially lock up. I would reccommend you save very regularly between levels and potentially consider creating more the one save file in order to prevent any corruption from occuring.

-The animations are somewhat still inferior to that of Megadimension Vii and the currently releasing Neptunia game. Some attacks feel slightly miss timed or awkward and some are even bugged out, Blanc hammer being the perfect example. Some of the walk animation's could also use with smoothening out and the symbol attack animations for the characters dont give clear visual feedback at all, making it at times frustrating for new players to handle attacking enemies in the field.

-The soundtrack is generally weaker than every other Neptunia game, nothing really standing out except for Plutia's theme, which is actually well executed and generally make chills go down your spine.

-Although the UI graphically may look amazing, the general feel is completely the opposite to other Neptunia games, which may make the transition between the two a little more awkward to get used to.

-Stelas Dungeon and the remake system in general is to HEAVILY relied on in terms of progression of the story and is probably my biggest concern in reccommending this game over the other's and could even point others in another direction if I didn't know prior to playing the game. The true ending of the game HEAVILY and I mean HEAVILY relies on you having previously used the Stelas Dungeon mini game mechanic, in order to unlock multiple levels to find various fragments. This means that you are literally waiting for a mini game that also involves RNG, in order to get the correct plans in order to progress the story. This game being played in the background (thankfully), progressing at 1 floor per 10 seconds, where climbing up 5000 or so floors is a requirement to unlock levels for unlocks of an ending... Just buy the super cheap DLC and save the frustration.

-The end game progression after that of the main story isn't really worth your time unless you either want to 100% the game or if you want to just get the appropriate costumes and weapons for that of your favourite characters from the series. Other than that, you can pretty much sweep through the end game mobs as long as your party is competent and is well balanced.

-Although minor, the new SP system narrows the players ability to be flexible with there character selection and the way they go about combat, as generally moves with the ability to generate SP are entirely superior to moves that can do moderate amounts of damage or break armor.

-It is reccommended that you play this with a controller, so if you don't have one, your experience might be somewhat awkward by comparison.

40744365.review:
TL;DR : Play Re;Birth2 before playing this. It's a good game with some mechanic changes which may take time getting used to

[i]Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth3 V Generation[/i] is the third installment of the Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth franchise. The game takes place after the events of [i[Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth: Sisters Generation[/i] so it is adviced to finish playing that game before proceeding to this one.

Majority of the story takes place in the alternate dimension. In here, our lovable main character, Neptune, Meets the narcoleptic Plutia, CPU of the atlernate Planeptune. In this alternate dimension, there also resides alternate versions of the other Nation's CPUs: Noire, Blanc and Vert, with little to no difference to their original counterparts.

This time around, the CPUs face on a new enemy faction, the Seven Sages, which composes of very familiar looking members [spoiler] Recycled assets *ahem*[/spoiler]. 

Here I'll talk about the Pros, the Neuts, and the Cons

[h1] PROS [/h1]

1. Nep-nep main character. Instant 10/10
2. Very Cheap OP DLC. Use it if you want to cheese through the early parts of the game. They fall off in performance in the late game
3. Pururutooooooo~
4. 3D CUTSCENES! EMERGERD! AND THE CHARACTERS WEAR THE COSTUME YOU EQUIPPED THEM WITH!

[h1] NEUTS [/h1]

1. [u]The Grind[/u]. I don't really mind this since I am used to grinding but others may find it repetitive and boring. 
2. [u]The new SP system[/u]. Unlike in the previous Neptunia Re;Birth games, the SP in this one is charged by dealing damage to enemy creatures. They also removed the EXE Drive bar. EX Finishers can now be activated depending on the amount of SP you hold. I personally don't like this one, the EXE drive bar of the previous game was already a good system, but I kinda understand why they changed it, as it can be easily be used to cheese through boss fights.
3. [u]3 Endings[/u]. The first game had 2 endings, the second game had more than 6. This one only has 3. Was kinda expecting more, but maybe I'm the only one complating about this
4. [u]Recycled Assets[/u]. Budget cuts? Maybe, but there is a difference between taking some old assets and using the entire things. Most of the dungeons here are dungeons you see on the previous games. Not just the dungeons, the mobs too. With only name and color changes. 

[h1] CONS [/h1]

1. [u]LACK OF ENGLISH VOICES[/u]. There is so many scenes, both main and side quest, that lack english voice acting. About more than 50% of the entire game lacks english voices. I'm not the type to use the english voice, but I know there are many people out there that do. And they will probably be surprised that despite this game having english voices in the options menu, there is not much english voices.
2. [u]FREQUENT CRASHES[/u]. This is the only Neptunia game that i have played that crashes very very frequently. One times it crashed after a boss fight and I have to do the damn thing again! I am not sure what is causing this. I have posted in the community and found out there are alot of people that have the same problem as I do. And as our goddess Neptune has said [url=http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1302297276]"Ugh! Debug your games properly, Idea Factory International!"[/url]
3. [u]STILL NO GRAPHICS OPTIONS[/u]. Now I kinda understand why this option doesn't exist, because it's a port from the Playstation. But it should be noted that unlike the Playstation, PCs don't always have the same specs. Some have high tier specs and some don't. I belong to the lower tier and I have been playing this game at lowest resolution at around 8-20 FPS. The game doesn't seem to be affected by game boosters. I have finished the previous game and I feel I am not getting the same experience as the higher tier owners do just because I have to deal with the low fps. 

Despite all these flaw, I would still give this game a solid 9/10. Most of the problems I stated are due to my own personal preference and poor economic status. Except for the crashes. Seriously. Fix it. Otherwise, Plutia will make you fix it~

Another addition to the Hyperdimension Neptunia series, with some interesting changes. New characters, story, and new areas. Here's some info for people who have played other HDN games:

Pro's and cons compared to other games in the series: 
+ Good soundtrack additions.
+ Doesn't have level design lameness of rebirth 2. 
+ A LOT of playable characters. More then 15.  
+ UI has been redone in places, with benefits. 

- Removed the ability to see the stat changes some items will have without equipping them. This is VERY annoying. 
- Stella's Dungeon hasn't been removed. It sucks slightly less but still sucks. 
- Keep's the second game's need to talk to a s***load of random people and get nothing from it. 
- Still has easy to miss key items that can fail to spawn, small chance of ruining a run. 

TL;DR: Solid game. Keeps some good from rebirth 2 and makes some new changes of it's own. Still has some problems holding back from the greatness that is the first, though.

First of all, I know this game from another game which are doesn't related to this game at all such as L4D2, PD2, etc. However, they are related because of steam workshop. I was interested and watch the anime and worth it. I saw this game and finally I can afford money to buy it.

Objectively, I highly recommend this game for hardcore fan of JRPG or one hour daily player like me. This game can be played for one hour per day because of fast battle yet entertaining moves and dialogues. The voice actings are really good both english and japanese although I recommend to play with japanese voices. The characters itself have unique and good role of the series, even the antagonist. Stella's Dungeon is really worth it to play while working my homework.

However, this game can be really tough if you don't grind XP and SP. The story itself can be really long for one event before you can progress.

As a summary, 9/10. Buy this game while on sale. Deluxe edition is recommended [spoiler] you can get an awesome stuff :) [/spoiler]. If you can't decide to play RB1, 2 or 3 first, it doesn't matter at all but I recommend play RB1 first to get better introduction to the series (I watch youtuber play RB1 and RB2). For low-end player [strike] like me [/strike], you need to setup your .exe file so it can exceed 2gb usage. If game still doesn't launch or outstanding 2 fps, sorry, you need another PC.

*First ending edit : After 100 hours playing [spoiler] with AFKs [/spoiler], I got good ending at the first run and true ending at the second run with back up save. I recommend to get the true ending first then get another ending. True ending will give you some stuff to help you progress through the post credit events or NG+. You can back up save to get all of the endings at one cycle but your gallery won't carried out. Unfortunately, it means that you need to play with same save data at least 3 times to get full gallery.

As I said above you can play this game 1 hour per day and even while do your homework, but this game is grindy and actually RNG based to get your drops so be careful to schedule your play time or you can play this game AFKs by only playing Stella's Dungeon and get your drop without hit any single button and without interruption, perhaps. Still 9/10, worth to play, worth to watch :)

36275820.review:
Neptune es arrastrada a una dimensión alternativa desde donde recorreremos la historia de los videojuegos partiendo de los años 80, en la que para mí es la mejor entrega de la franquicia hasta la fecha.

El sistema de combate se ha perfeccionado respecto a las entregas anteriores y se ha ajustado bien la dificultad (importante no activar los DLC's de personajes durante el primer walkthrough si no queremos hacer el juego demasiado fácil). 

El diseño de mazmorras no es gran cosa, pero al menos deja atrás la mediocridad y dejadez de la anterior entrega y el guión posiblemente sea el mejor de la franquicia además del más divertido y rico en referencias, con una deliciosa Lady Plutia representando al lado macarra y socarrón de la Sega de la era Megadrive/Genesis.

Por lo demás no es un juego muy innovador: se reutilizan muchos assets usados en las anteriores entregas, así como bastantes sonidos y músicas, y se sigue usando el monótono formato "visual novel" para narrar la historia, pero si sabes a lo que vas te encantará.

PD: El capítulo de la batalla contra ese virus para la industria que son los juegos "pay to win" es para enmarcar.

+ Nepgear, being shifted from main character to a supporting character, is being bullied a lot in this game (Yes, this is a positive. Just love seeing her reactions)

+ The maker charas (Except for Compa and IF), doesn't have any roles in the main story, but they have plenty of sub events and even CGs. (This is better imo, with this the main story's doesn't feel too "cramped"). Also, in those sub-events, neptune isn't the only one who interacted with those chara. The other goddessess did too, which is nice to see

+ Iris Heart

[h1] NEGATIVES :	[/h1]

+ I experienced a lot of bugs in this game. the most annoying one is being unable to see some CGs in the story (4 Cgs). Thank God this is fixed and not an issue in new game+


[h1] CONCLUSION :	[/h1]

Now I understand why people said victory is the best nep game. This game really gives a real "nep" vibes and enjoyment compared to the other rebirth games. Gotta try VII and see whose better though.

[b] 9/10	[/b]

At this point I just laid back and prepared for my daily dose of Nep, but the dose was different!
Quite a few improvements have been made since the previous instalment (which really didn't bring anything new to the table, but got me my fix):

*Sorting function for quests and some other listings
*Ranged attacks are much easier to use
*Game runs much smoother (might be personal, last game had FPS issues)
*New gigantic dungeons added to combat improved FPS

I have difficulty deciding which hpn is my personal favorite, but this one with the better remake system is much more user-friendly

33774372.review:
Well, how do I start this... maybe with the caveat: for me, this is a "Do you recommend this game? - Yes, but...".

Now, let's try to get a few more details. The game itself is set in an interesting world, and while the characters might be a bit childish at times, they are still recognizable and likable characters. Plus. a game set in "Gamindustri", referencing games and gaming and stuff, and constantly nuking the 4th wall -- that has to be fun. As far as I'm concerned, I liked it.

Don't misunderstand, though. The game may be set in "Gamindustri" and the 4 nations may represent 4 console manufacturers, but the actual story is a standard fantasy-type story where some bad guys want to topple the good guys. "Gaming" is more a of general world theme, not so much the theme of the story.

You may want to be careful though. The visuals are nice but somewhat dated, the story is told in a visual novel style with endless streams of text boxes giving a lot childish dialogue that can be tiring. Some of it is voice acted, but many scenes are not.

Also, the game is very repetitive. Like they only have a handful of dungeons (which is where the gameplay happens), and reuse them again and again and again. The same applies to monsters, although those might at least get a color change :-) And they have more boss fights than bosses, so expect repeats there as well, even for story bosses.

Some aspects of the game might feel a bit grindy, like having to walk through a dungeon again and again until it gives you the item that you are looking for. Upgrading lily ranks or challenges to get the char upgrades attached to some tiers is just pointless grinding as well.

In addition to the actual story the game also gives you quests... which are forgettable, to say the least. Not only are they just standard fetch/kill quests -- I've stopped reading the texts pretty soon as those made no sense at all.

The game can also get annoying with it's inventory, since there's no sorting. If you want to check whether you have a certain item, select the category, and read through the list until you find it, or hope that you didn't miss it if you didn't see it. I'd also like to sell off the tons of garbage materials for some extra cash, but it feels too tiring due to the lack of useful sorting options.

I only have one negative about this game so I will get it out of the way first and that is that the intro music to this game is the worst out of the 3 rebirth games, I loved the intro songs from the first 2 but no matter how much I listened to this one I could not get on with it.

As a big fan of the neptunia series this game did not dissapoint in any way, the battle system is basically the same as the first 2 except it has a slightly new skin and they changed how they "EXE drive" works, also there are more mini cutscenes in this game than the other rebirths have had.

The big bad this time around is a group called "the seven sages" it has some new villans in the group but some of them you will recognise from the other rebirth games and I liked that they were included, before you get to end game there is a total of 24 characters (if you got the dlc) you can switch between for your main party, including 2 If's, 2 compa's and 2 falcom's, so feel free to have a party of if's and compa's if you so choose, there is also as much customisation gear as there was in the other games.

The story this time involves poor nep-nep getting sent to another dimension and trying to find her way home, the other cpu's are in it still in the other dimension just obviously have no idea who neptune is and there is also a new addition "Plutia" who is planeptune's cpu; which some people may be familiar with if they got the dlc on rebirth 1. you will learn to fear the Plutia as everybody else in the game does :P 
Histoire is also still in this game but a smaller version (which is adorable).

For me Blanc has always been my least favourite cpu as I have never found her that likeable but in this game while she does still have her mood swings and anger; she also shows a lot more of a softer and warmer side and is more relatable and started to win me over. 
Because of the majority of the fan's disliking nepgear as the protagonist of rebirth 2 she gets treated very badly in this game, I hope you are all happy :'( while I of course prefer Neptune as the protaganist I did not dislike nepgear and she did not deserve all of the hate lol. 

For those of you like me who disliked all of the share juggling in rebirth 2, you will be happy to know that this game does not have any share juggling, while there are still shares in it they are not really that important and often get switched around at the start of a new chapter, I got planeptune to like 70% of the shares, than at the start of the new chapter planeptune was down to 10%

Stella's dungeon also makes a return in this game and this time has 10000 floors! I can not say how long it takes normally as I had the DLC and with it each floor only takes a second.

The game is very good which comes as no surprise to me and a very highly recommend it.

31719463.review:
I bought this game in March and played it for about 64 hours, then abandoned it for a while. Then I picked it up again today and realized why. Re;Birth 3 is a valiant effort at revitalizing the series, but it just doesn't do enough.

First off, the battle system has been substantially modified. Now there is no EXE gauge - instead, your SP gauge does double duty. Suddenly, Rush attacks actually matter. No longer can you half-heartedly assign some spare points to somewhat-decent Rush attacks; now you have to think carefully and balance between all three types. Now everybody has to worry about Rushing. It adds a little more strategy to the gameplay - though I will say that grinding your SP back up after a boss battle can be quite a chore, especially when your fastest characters keep killing enemies before the slower ones even get a chance to touch them.

Inside dungeons, the hidden treasure system has changed slightly. Now instead of using that annoying radar, you look for shadows of invisible blocks (think Mario) on the ground and hit them. They all give you credits, but only one per run of a dungeon gives you an item. So basically, it's the same as before, but they're easier to find. Heck, in some dungeon layouts, you can even see the box shimmering in the air. That said, though, the developers continued their infuriating trend of hiding important items in them. Plans, weapons, armor, even [i]costumes[/i]. The cooler the item, the lower its spawn rate is, with costumes and accessories reaching nigh-impossible levels. To give you an idea, I spent three hours doing nothing but going in and out of Ario Plateau (or was it Luji? Screw it, I can't be bothered to remember), waiting for Blanc's school uniform and accompanying hat to spawn. And apparently I'm one of the [i]lucky[/i] ones. If you want to unlock all the cosmetic options in the game... may Noire have mercy on your soul.

Another thing that got a spit-shine is Stella's Dungeon. It's much more straightforward now, and the DLC bundled with the game (the base game, mind you - for once, they've decided to give you the non-cosmetic DLC for free) makes the first several areas go by pretty easily. Uzume hasn't left my side in... well, forever, actually. It eventually becomes hard to lose at Stella's Dungeon, assuming you exercise a minimal amount of caution.

Dungeon layouts are, again, recycled. You'll see a lot of familiar places that pervaded the first two games of the series, though - like Re;Birth 2 - this game adds a couple more to the mix, some of which I found greatly enjoyable. The Luji Plateau layout is full of whimsy, and I found the Lowee Castle layout's myriad winding corridors to be a joy to wander, confusing as they may be. That said, there's still a lot of recycling. There's a lot more dungeons in this game than in the other two games, meaning you'll be running into the same layouts perhaps even [i]more[/i] than you did in them. Plus, all the layouts from the first two games are laughably hostile toward the new hidden treasure system, as their floors are too detailed/dark to see the shadows. There's a plan that shows the treasure spots on the minimap, but still. When you're grinding for that Noire weapon you absolutely HAVE to have, it gets painful to just bounce around like an idiot hoping you're close enough to the box for it to register a hit.

Which brings me to a new feature: "challenges." There are certain "challenges" that can increase characters' stats, grant them plans, and so on. These range from "jump X times" to "spend X battles outside the party." The vast majority of them, though, require the character to be the leader. And with one, two, three... 28 characters in this game, this gets painful FAST. Heck, I've had Nepgear as my leader for pretty much as long as I've had her, and I'm still nowhere near maxing out her jumping challenge. Oh, and did I mention? Each character's standard EXE attack is locked behind a "use skills X times" challenge. So you have to do some grinding before anyone becomes worth using. And once your first few characters do get their EXE attacks, you won't want to use anyone else. Looks like Histoire is gonna be a permanent member of my lineup.

Then there's the story. It's nothing as good as the second game, but it's still pretty competent. There's ups, downs, and so on and so forth. Even the villains get comfortable amounts of screentime. The second game had a hard time striking a balance, but this game - despite having more villains - gives each of them enough time to feel like they were worth including. I will say, though, that the recycled boss fights get old fast. Come on, even the second game had a few fights that weren't Underling or the Four Felons. Fortunately, there's only three endings this time, so you don't have to undo the Change Dungeon on Millennium Labyrinth five thousand times just to get 100% CG completion.

And last up... the translation. I'll come out and say it: it's just as bad as in the second game. Fortunately, the most brutalized characters (Nepgear and Ram) are background characters in this game, so it's not as noticeable. The memes, though, are in full swing. More so than they were in the second game, since Neptune is the main character again. Be afraid. Fortunately, there's a fanmade patch for this game, too, so it's playable. Then again, IFI shouldn't be forcing us to resort to these extremes in the first place.

However, it really cannot be understated how much stuff there is in this game. Not content - [i]stuff[/i]. There's a zillion dungeons to mindlessly wander in search of that dag-blasted LASOU Uniform, there's a zillion different characters to buy weapons (and make accessories) for, there's a zillion different plans to make and challenges to complete, there's a zillion different enemies to get item drops from, the list goes on and on. Re;Birth 3 is by far the most egregious of the trilogy in terms of mind-numbing grinding time asked of the player. Never has any other game - even the other Neptunia ones - so thoroughly crushed my desire to complete it - or even finish it. That's right. I haven't even finished the game. I'm sitting around in Chapter 8 right now because I've come to see the game as a chore. The rewards I get for farming enemies and making plans are meaningless when they're just the exact same things as in the other games. Why bother buying all these weapons, accessories, and costumes when I already have them in Re;Birth 2? This game recycles almost every item that it contains (except for, obviously, the Plutia- and Peashy-specific ones), making them worthless. And the story isn't bad, but it's nowhere near good enough to keep me engaged.

This is why I said the game tries to improve upon the formula, but doesn't go far enough. If you've played either of the first two games - and if you're looking at this game, then I'm assuming you have - then you aren't missing anything. There's really no reason to buy this one. The second one was worth buying, despite the repetitiveness, because of its story. This one has no draws. Just ignore it and move on to something else. I hear that Megadimension shakes things up a bit - maybe you can try that.

31420541.review:
I'm making this review after my first playthrogh, 65 hours-long.

Okay, out of the three Re;Birth games this is the one I feel I havel to review. Why? Because it's awesome.

I'll assume here that you know about the Neptunia series and know what you're getting into. If you do not, I strongly recommend that you start with either Re:Birth 1 or 2, and check gameplay videos first. This series is notoriously low-budget, so many might be put off by how the game feels.

TL;DR: Gameplay is mostly the same, though there are a few nice balancing changes and some great quality of life changes. Story-wise, in my opinion Re;Birth 3 is miles ahead of 1 and 2. As a Neptunia game, this is a solid 9/10.

Pros:

+ Awesome story. It's like the devs were like "this is the 3rd game, how about we make an actual story?" and they did it. Some surprises, some plot twists, stuff that I didn't come to expect from this series. 
+ Plutia. Amazing new character! Her being in the story is part of what made it so awesome.
+ Different dimension, different versions of known characters. Noire, Blanc and Vert behave mostly the same, but they feel more interesting this time around. They also interact more with each other instead of mostly Neptune, something that bothered me in past games.
+ Lack of Uni, Ram and Rom. Okay, I know this is a personal opinion but they were very uninteresting and I'm glad they barely showed up here.
+ EXE bar is now the same as SP and EXE skills now cost more bars. Now the tough fights aren't about you spamming EXEs anymore, and you don't have to spam rush attacks every time you go into a dungeon to build up EXE, since SP doesn't diminish on its own.
+ I feel like I should mention Plutia again, for being so awesome.
+ By pressing Y (Xbox gamepad) on quests and plans, you can now see where items drop, where monsters are found, if the dungeon needs to be changed or not, and etc. Extremely useful.
+ Stella's dungeon is more polished. The stuff she finds can really help you out.
+ No more scanning for hidden items in dungeons. Now you look for shadows and jump on them to reveal a hidden box with stuff, there are around 4 to 6 boxes in dungeons and only one has items. Unfortunately, in dark cave dungeons it's literally impossible to see the shadow. And fortunatelly, around halfway through the game you get the plan that lets you see them on the mini-map.
+Challenge system. You get certain in-game achievments for each character for things like damage dealt, enemies killed, skills used or how many times you jumped. Each challenge has multiple levels and each level will award you with permanent stat gains. In short, the more you play a character as a leader or in the main party, the stronger she'll be.
+ Shares no longer necessary to get different endings (or plans, that I know of). Honestly, shares were just a bothersome requirement in previous games.
+ A few dungeon bosses have nasty surprises prepared for you. I'm looking at you, Nurse Binder and Gargoyle.

Comparing this to previous Neptunia games, I can't think of many cons. But there you go..

Cons:

- Nations in the other dimension are separated from the world map. Now you have to click on them, go to their screen and then you see their respective dungeons. Visually it looks great, but now there's more loading time.
- Most playable characters aren't actually on your party. You get every Maker character plus the Oracles but they're just add-ons, none of them are really with you, which means they don't take part in the storyline. Most people won't care about it, but it made me refrain from using them on my first playthrough.

That's about it, I guess.. IMO this game is better in almost every way compared to the other two. If you liked them, don't hesitate to get this one.

30885488.review:
El mejor Neptunia de la saga Rebirth, sin dudas.

Tiene mejor historia, tiene momentos épicos y memorables (que un Neptunia produzca eso, ya es mucho decir), mejor jugabilidad, algunas mejoras gráficas y de interfaz y por supuesto, mucho más moe y waifus que nunca xD.

Actualizaron la jugabilidad, lo cual le viene muy bien:

- Ahora ya no existe la barra EX. Ahora existe una única barra de SP y tanto las técnicas SP como las EX utilizan la misma barra, ya no es una sola sino que cada personaje tiene la suya propia. Hicieron ajustes al balance y consumo de las técnicas SP, ahora son más efectivas, pero hay que tener cuidado porque hay que ser más estratégico para jugar porque te puedes consumir todo el SP sin poder hacer técnicas EX cuando las necesites.

- Ahora los personajes no CPU (CyberConnect2, MarvelousAQL, Falcom, etc) pueden entrar en un estado llamado "Awakened", que si bien no es como el HDD de las CPU, si hacen que sus ataques y técnicas sean un poco más poderosas.

- Ahora los personajes que quedan K.O, antes de morir, tienen la opción de intercambiarse por el personaje que está de apoyo, lo cual me parece genial.

Tiene mucho del primer Neptunia: Vuelve Neptune como CPU principal y protagonista, con la ayuda de las otras CPUs principales, aunque también después aparecen sus hermanas y son personajes jugables también. Tiene una historia bastante buena y al final me gustó mucho el antagonista principal. En total yo logré desbloquear un total de 28 personajes, cosa nada dificil de obtener, todos jugables.

En resumen: A mi me ha gustado mucho este Neptunia, considerando sus puntos fuertes y sus puntos malos (que los tiene).

Respecto de los bugs, caídas de framerate y crasheos, tristemente es una constante en este tipo de ports, asi que lo más recomendado antes de encontrarse con esos problemas y tirarse los pelos de la rabia, primero es desactivar el ajuste de escala de la pantalla (eso se hace en el .exe del juego), luego parchear el juego para que use más de 2GB de memoria. Los que tengan tarjetas Nvidia, meterse al Panel de Control de Nvidia y activar algunos parámetros como filtrado anisotrópico, luminosidad, sincronización vertical, etc. Hay varias guías en internet sobre cómo hacer lo que he explicado muy resumidamente. Notarán de inmediato la mejora de rendimiento, andará a 1080p y a 60 FPS estables y sin crasheos.

30016283.review:
Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth is back for the PC with its third installment and it heavily leans on its two predecessors and their accomplishments. That being said, while it heavily relies on premade assets and basic gameplay ideas, it still delivers on new features for the game. Sadly it falls completely short in the stability department. 

I joked about it for part two, but this time, if you know the first game, you really know most of this one. It copies every map of Re;Birth 1 and some of 2. As the maps of 2 were sometimes lacking in depth, this is a welcome rebrand for Re;Birth 3, if lazy. And of course nearly no new enemy types are added, just rebranded - if at all - and sent out. You will even remember some of the quest texts. While this could draw the ire of many players, the story theme of "A world in the Past" actually makes it an irony in itself. So if you can adopt it to your game's storyline, you might let them get away with it. 
The story is set in another dimension, the Ultradimension, and has Neptune being exiled to it from her own home the Hyperdimension of Re;Birth 2. Yes, this game is an actual sequel! In her first days in the Ultradimension, Neptune quickly realizes that not all is as she remembered... and the future has yet to be written for her and others. In this setting, the game excels in its most important asset yet again, the meta-story and its jokes about the console wars of the past. Many of its easter eggs, secrets and jokes make more than up for its grindy gameplay and exhausting repetition even for those that don't follow Red's wifey fetish or like to play dress up with digital assets. All of this is delivered in the now common format of a novel-rpg hybrid. 
Within this genre, this game is as casual or hard as you want to as it continues the trilogy's idea of "play like you want". You quickly get the plans and choice to craft harder or easier enemies, to get more experience or to just play the game normally. That being repeated even from Re;Birth 2, much HAS changed in terms of gameplay to its two predecessors! The old % grinds have been replaced with them being tied to the story and are only part of the actual immersive gameplay of the quests. Further the eternal button mashing to scan for hidden treasures in maps has been replaced with the "Super Neptune Sisters" blocks you can see hover in all treasure locations in a ghostly outline. While only one of them offers treasure like before, all offer a small monetary benefit for hitting them. And it saves the liftetime of your X button.
The biggest change to gameplay though is the removal of the party shared exe drive and the variable status of SP, this games type of mana. Now its maximum is always 1000. While it was feasible to have heavy-hitters before with characters like Falcom with immense hit counts collecting your exe drive, your rush attacks now actually refill your own SP and only those. This bar works as your exe drive as well as your mana pool per character. So slow characters tend to fall behind in refilling their abilities unless you switch to defending for them to catch up. This also devalues the super exe attacks, which are far less rewarding than a traditional guard break combo before unleashing the necessary amount of SP with a normal SP skill on the enemy. The gameplay has truly been changed.
Stella's Dungeon also makes a return, this time with 20 floors of one dungeon to clear. The gameplay has been streamlined and flavored with side-characters you in the past only talked with. They can do the scouting work for her and new ones get added per cleared floor, offering up new abilities or rare items and monsters to find. It also takes less time than before, at least with the DLC plans. As in Re;Birth 2, even sped up, the last dungeons took A DAY, none will take more than half an hour with it.
The game's crafting system still focuses most on clothes and outside changes on the CPUs. Unlike Re;Birth 2, though, the developers could reuse all assets from Re;Birth 1 and thus the immense long list of accessories from Re;Birth 1 makes a resounding return. Don't expect anything new, but if you loved some in Re;Birth 1 or 2, the chance is high you can recreate them in Re;Birth 3 all over again. There will be no lack of recipes to grind for, unless you cheapen your experience so far with the easy mode recipes, that you run out of MB.

Sadly, the greatest problem of this game is THE EXACT SAME Re;Birth 2 had. It tends to crash during repeated transmissions between zones in speed grinds in medium to long play sessions. And while before it could also happen in battles with graphical glitches in components of characters warning you about an impending crash, this time it has hit the novel-rpg sequences instead. Once one of the story assets turns into a weird cut out black blop or the background disappears, abandon all hope. Before the sequence ends, the game WILL crash. Unlike Re;Birth 2 there is no chance you reach a savepoint by then. Save often and restart your game at least every two hours to prevent bad surprises. This game was not polished or properly ported. Long play sessions will risk your current advances in the game at any moment. While the lack of graphics in the sequences can be funny, the loss of a hard fought boss might not. At least restart before a boss fight at the save point and make sure to never do long grind sessions without going out of the dungeon or to a savepoint to keep the data.

Like with its predecessors, my main interest in the game still stems from the light humor of it and the quirky story. And it delivered well, despite or especially because of some darker themes in this new installment! It might have been one if not the best of the trilogy I played. I can only compliment the author of many of the jokes. While not all work all the time, I found myself enjoying and laughing. And in the end that is what matters. 
The gameplay has been diversified a little and the minigame actually became a proper minigame to enjoy. Before I called the gameplay solala, now it can be considered average. So the game overall is already better than any of its predecessors, of which it heavily borrowed in assets and gameplay anyway. As always, the fun lies in the characters and story, if you love to break the fourth wall, have some wifeys or a digital dress up party... or a nostalgic grind. 
Play it your way, and try to enjoy the insanity of our Hyperdimension's Neptunia. But if you are reading this, you surely had some fun with its prior installments and thus you can't go wrong here. Just consider the stability issues past the two hour mark per session!

My final verdict for Hyperdimension Neptunia is finish it, including the Social Games DLC storyline, Stella's Dungeon included!

29612508.review:
Tercera y última parte de la trilogía "Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth".

Tras la hostia que se pegó R;B2 (que fue una decepción general, aunque a mí me gustó y considero que hizo algunas cosas mejor que R;B1), nuestras CPUs vuelven a la carga con una tercera parte, que a mi parecer, [b]es la mejor.[/b]

En R;B3, a diferencia del caso de R;B1 y R;B2,  [b]la historia empieza justo donde acaba la de R;B2.[/b]

(Recordatorio de que [b]R;B1 NO ES CANON, solo algunos pequeños elementos de su historia[/b]. Lo digo porque he visto muchos casos en los que le han cascado análisis negativo a R;B2 porque no continuaba la historia de R;B1, no se desarrollaba en la misma dimensión. Sí, por mucho que os joda, [b]el verdadero lore de Neptunia empieza con R;B2.[/b])

[b]R;B3 es una mezcla que junta lo mejor de las dos entregas anteriores.[/b] [b]Vuelve a recuperar la frescura y dinamismo que tenían los diálogos en R;B1[/b] (debido a que Neptune vuelve a ser la prota y Plutia es amor) y [b]los villanos del juego tienen cierta profundidad y son un grupo variado[/b] (este era el problema que le veía a R;B1, que te pasabas el juego detrás del mismo personaje todo el juego. R;B2 tenía un repertorio de villanos más amplio, cosa que agradecí.)

El juego cuenta con [b]un nuevo HUD renovado que se siente muy fresco[/b] y un [b]pequeño (gran) cambio en el sistema de combate: la eliminación del Medidor EXE.[/b]

[b]Ahora las Unidades EXE, habilidades PH y demás, comparten la misma barra de PH[/b], cosa que hace al juego más difícil, ya que no puedes lanzar Unidades EXE con la tranquilidad de que podrás seguir usando boosts o heals. Habrá que pensar y planear mucho más cada turno. [b]A excepción de ese cambio, el sistema de combate sigue siendo igual.[/b]

Todo el sistema de Planos sigue igual, aunque en R;B3 [b]introducen los "Big Dungeon Changes", que cambian los enemigos fuertes y los objetos recolectables en una mazmorra[/b]. En el apartado  "Sistema" podemos ver que además de los que aparecieron en R;B2, hay nuevos planos que cambian la BGM entre otras cosas.

[b]El sistema de búsqueda de tesoros también lo han cambiado.[/b] En vez de ir spammeando el botón como locos para que el área los detectase, [b]ahora aparecerán cubos flotantes invisibles contra los que tendremos que saltar[/b] (al más puro estilo Super Mario) para que nos salgan objetos.

[b]También han introducido unos "minidesafíos" por personaje que nos otorgarán recompensas[/b] (del rollo: "Salta 100 veces con Neptune" y nos recompensarán subiéndonos alguna estadística o con un Plano que le desbloquee algo al personaje. Un nuevo sistema que me ha gustado mucho, ya que nos recompensan de forma muy grata si usamos mucho a personajes concretos.)

[b]Ahora tener a una líder u otra también influirá en el combate[/b], ya que al recorrer X metros con un personaje, nos darán un Plano para desbloquearle una pasiva al equipo cuando X personaje esté de líder (por ejemplo, la pasiva de líder de Neptune es reducir el coste de PH al activar HDD).

[b]Stella's Dungeon ha sido mejorado y ahora es de gran ayuda.[/b] Los tiempos de exploración en las mazmorras se han reducido mucho, Stella encuentra objetos realmente necesarios, puede tener un acompañante, etc... Nada que ver con el de R;B2, que era bastante inútil y coñazo (sobretodo si queríamos el 100% en logros).

R;B3 (además de todos los cambios mencionados antes en el gameplay), también [b]incluye escenas hechas con el motor del juego[/b] que le dan aún más dinamismo a algunas escenas, además del [b]Nepstation[/b] (un divertido programa con noticias chorra y preguntas) entre otras cosillas.

Mencionar también que [b]es el R;B con el mayor número jugable de personajes y además el único con postgame[/b] (y bastante decente, a lo Pokémon Oro/Plata, ya veréis ;) )

Tampoco os preocupéis por el tema de los finales, [b]solo tiene 3[/b] (no como el maldito R;B2, que tenía 9 y la gran mayoría eran chorras)

Pero no todo es de color de rosa con R;B3, ya que la [b]sigue arrastrando una asignatura pendiente de los dos anteriores juegos: el reciclaje[/b].

[b]Las mazmorras vuelven[/b] (una vez más, sí) [b]a ser recicladas de los juegos anteriores sin apenas ningún cambio.[/b]

[b]Sí, volvemos a tener el caso de muchas mazmorras idénticas en aspecto pero con el nombre cambiado y distintos enemigos.[/b]

Todas las mazmorras de tipo "bosque", iguales, todas las de tipo "fábrica", también y etc, etc... Eso es algo aún pendiente en la franquícia.

[b]R;B3 solo trae tres tipos nuevos de mazmorra[/b] (y se olvida de algunas de R;B2 que a mí me molaban). Entre ellas, hay dos cuyo concepto me hubiese encantado que se hubiese exprimido más, que son [b]las "megamazmorras"[/b].

Las "megamazmorras" (término acuñado por mí) [b]son mazmorras gigantes, muy grandes.[/b] Las dos únicas que hay me molaron mucho y me da mucha rabia que el concepto no se exprimiese más.

Con los enemigos [b]también sigue pasando lo mismo.[/b] [b]Enemigos idénticos pero con nombre distinto[/b] (sin ni siquiera un triste  reskin), [b]enemigos cuya apariencia no corresponde con su nombre[/b] (sí, el dogoo metálico sigue siendo igual que el original), etc, etc...

Otro punto negativo es el que [b]obviamente está en inglés y tiene texto PARA ABURRIR.[/b] Así que si no tienes paciencia o el inglés, nanay, pasaría.


Y eso es todo. Un punto y final a la trilogía R;B que empecé con muchas ganas y no me ha decepcionado, es más, [b]me ha parecido el mejor en historia, gameplay, etc... En todo, vamos.[/b]

[b]Todo y que podría haber dado para mucho más[/b], es la experiencia Re;Birth [b]definitiva[/b] y [b]más pulida[/b], [b]junta lo mejor[/b] de las dos anteriores entregas y [b]añade bastante.[/b]

Recomendado.

29576097.review:
NOTE: I had to use a patch (4GB patch of ntcore) to be able to play it, without it the game is completly unplayable after the first battle. Even with the patch I have experienced a couple of crashes after the boss battles, so I was forced to defeat them again and use the skip button to rush the dialog that I have already read before the crash. I have a simple computer (64-bit Win 7 with 8GB RAM & intel core), so if you have a similar or inferior computer and you not like to play games that would crash very often, then I DON'T recommend you this game.
------

Even if I'm only played Nintendo and PC games at all my life, I always loved to read back then everything about old consoles (from the Atari 2600 to the Xbox) like their best games and their background. When I heard that there is a game where the characters are anthropomorphed old consoles, I definitely wanted to check it out and I'm not dissapointed (would be perfect if there was a Neo Geo/SNK character in the game). The main concept of the hyperdimension universe is a big what if where Sega still do consoles after the Dreamcast because Sega is BFF with the tsundere of Sony instead Sony be the one who doom it.

Don't get fooled with the general low scores of the VITA version, this game is very good! It's a good turn-based JRPG game with decent customization, lovable characters and great dialog. The best thing is that you no need to grind in order to complete the story mode, just face a couple enemies in the chapter dungeon and use periodically Stella's app is enough to complete the plans that you need to unlock extra dungeons (the postgame is a completly another theme).

I just have a few complaints about the game (outside of the already mentioned crashes) and are things that prevents it to be an awesome game to the level of Paper Mario:The Thousand-years Door (since are similars in at some extent) like presentation of the player elements like cutomization & items, the common monsters are not memorables and the most notory one: the dungeons are literally the same in most cases and there is nothing else to do than just run into the event crytal and defeat any monster that cross in your way.

This is the first game of the franchise that I have played so I can guarantee that there is not need to play any other game before this one to enjoy it.

TL;DR - If you have a very powerful computer and want to play a good Turn-Based JRPG with hilarious writting, get this game.

 RESUMEN RÁPIDO DE LA HISTORIA: Por azares del destino nuestra querida, amada y super kawaii protagonista Neptune acaba en una dimension alternativa a la suya, donde aunque existen versiones de Noire, Blanc y Vert en su papel de diosas(O CPU >_>) no hay otra Nep, en su lugar hay una ....perezosa constantemente cansada llamada Plutia. 28769594.review:
Nep-nep is back and this time with more characters than ever! Overall this iteration of the anime JRPG is the best for me so far. The story takes you on a fun ride with lively characters and great humor, without jeopardizing the integrity of the overarching plot. 

1. The characters get a lot more action in this game compared to previews iterations, with more dialogue even for the side characters. Plutia as a new characters really brings another dimension to the whole trope theme, and, although unfamiliar at first, quickly became one of my favourites of the series. Even the bad guys seems a lot more real compared to the typical conquer the world villain, and all of them are redeemed in the end. 

2. The UI is improved greatly, with a whole new menu, great new battle UI, and separate maps for the different nations. Access to an improved Stella's Dungeon early in the game really helps with collecting materials and completing plans. 

3. A lot more dungeons this time around, together with an improved Stella's Dungeon, make completing plans a lot less tedius. The new change dungeon plans also provides an access to challenging bosses a lot early in the game. 

Overall this game is a really fun ride, and I recommend it to anyone who is a lover of JRPG and anime games. Definitely check out Re;Birth 1 too, as it establishes the characters and makes this game a lot more enjoyable. If you haven't played the previews games, this game is not completely unrelatable for new players too.

28380802.review:
Re;birth3. Wew. This was a fun experience. Introduced another new dimension (The Ultradimension) 2 new waifus (Peashy and Plutia) and a ton of new things to do. Let me begin on the improvements from the last 2 games

1. The menus now looks more vibrant and better to look at. The old one was fairly bland and not much, but this one now looks stunning and nice too look at every time. 
2. They removed the search system (couldn't use that at all without a plan) into a hidden block type deal where the blocks are fairly easy to find but could be missed in a quick glance
3. Stella's Dungeon has been improved a ton, now including a partnering system
4. THE END GAME DOES NOT MEAN YOU RESTART. FINALLY. There are multiple after-game things you can do, like fight bosses and such.
5. Nep-TV. Adds a bit more depth and connection to the games in my own opinion.
6. The map system is now divided up into sections (You have to go into a world map then choose, for example, Planeptune, just to enter an area).
7. It's not as much of a grind to finish the game.

Also, unlike Re;Birth2, this game actually has a good story that isn't 100% doom, gloom, and all serious. Plutia being my favourite character for how many times she makes situations better by doing horrible things. Nepgear also gets an improvement, seeming to be more of a comic relief type character and not the serious younger sister as before. Neptune may be a bit more mean spirited in a way, and even was lazy to do some fairly important and life threatening things, but I didn't note it and forgot about it. 

All in all, this game is how the original Neptunia 3 helped the series. Made improvements on things that needed fixing, and overall was good. One of my fav J-RPGs of all time, and I will soon not forget this journey. Well, depending on how Megadimension treats me.

28240178.review:
This is the third subjective, unbiased and totally unfunny review yet again but for HyperD Nep VGen. Nothing has changed. It’s still a JRPG trough and trough. For the third time you play teenager girls having an adventure by visiting dungeons, fighting monsters while they attempt to break the 4th wall to make fun of popculture and videogames.

And this time the writing is back to form. The girls take nothing serious and get sidetracked a lot by talking nonsense even in front of impending doom. And It’s gloriously entertaining! Some of the situations the girls find themselves in are so hilariously stupid that they become good again.
 
The same gameplay pattern too? Yes! Follow the story as visual novel, go to dungeon, fight monsters, beat boss, continue, Repeat! New is that instead of a single overhead worldmap, the world is separated into small subscreens. Some of them get unlocked by going into a dungeon from one side and leaving trough the other. Clever!

Stella’s Dungeon, the spelunker mini game, is also back. And unlike the previous version (which forced me to not 100% the last game) it’s fast, more complex, yet simplified. There is still a gigantic amount of items to craft, to loot and use but it won’t bulldozer over you because the devs finally added a feature to check which monster, in which dungeon drops which item: Making the constant alt-tabbing to a browser window to check the games wikipedia obsolete.

The combat system got changed a tiny bit as well. You can’t spam superattacks anymore, cuz actionpoints don’t automatically refill when leaving a dungeon. Actionpoints need to be gathered by attacking monsters with rush attacks. Makes the combat much more challenging. But overall it stays the exact same. Yay for animation-skip-button!

Shares of the nations no longer come into play to progress the story. The 3 possible endings will be triggered by watching optional VN-events. There is more details to it, but please check one of the dozens guides that explain how to get the endings. Thanks! 

The humour is marvelous, all characters loveable, all essential DLC’s are already integrated into the game without any additional purchase. This is the game Rebirth 1+2 should’ve ben from begin with. Without second thought, I recommend V Generation to those that like the prequels or JRPG's in general.

27857344.review:
I’m not too sure how to review this game, so i’ll just point out what you can find here.


[i]For a new player:[/i]
Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth3 V Generation is a good game and it doesn't require having played the first two games to follow the story. If you're new to the franchise, this game is a good starting point, well, actually any game is a good starting point.
For how I see it the games of this franchise provide not an excellent game, but a fun experience overall. 
Combat is very simple but it works and it's been a bit tweaked to make it harder to spam ultimate attacks, making those special abilities more likely to be used in battle (in the previous games those were almost useless).
Storytelling uses a visual-novel style like the previous games and there are a ton of anime and games references (some very obscure, like the pineapple salad for macross). The scenes tend to be veeery long, and while the dialogues are well written sometimes they drag on for too much, but you can skip them.
A peculiar feature is the remake system, basically a crafting system that lets you create new items, gain new abilities and change the monsters in dungeons, it ends up being very simple, but it's a good addition to boost the replayability of dungeons.
If you like anime games, I'd say either nep1 or this are a must buy.


[i]For a nep player:[/i]
Most of it is pretty much more of the same classic nep, with an arguably better story, fun characters (all of the nep1+2 team) and dungeons and some small improvements. This time the story is a continuation of nep2 and is not set in an alternate universe. 
The exe drives now require sp (and many of the classic ones need to be unlocked via character challenges) and you'll probably have to initially rely on the normal special abilities, which I found great, because in previous games I ended up not using these normal ones at all, with the exception of compa’s healing.
Dungeons are more diversified and the new ones are really cool, but there are pretty much no new monsters introduced in this game. 
The other two main additions are the character challenges from Fairy Fencer F (basically little stat bonuses you get for doing stuff with your characters) and a post game state where you can choose if you want to jump into NG+ or keep playing.




This game usually gets huge discounts so you should wait for one of those and then you're guaranteed to have a game worthy of 30+ hours of fun with neptune and her friends.
I recommend buying the DLC since it helps in the most frustrating rng part of the game, the Stella's dungeon.


[i]So, overall:[/i]


+ Well written wacky story
+ All the characters from nep 1+2
+ Character challenges
+ Remake system 
+ Fair price with regular discounts 


- Stella's dungeon (but it's way more useful than in nep2)
- Dialogues scenes are too long
- Tends to get very repetitive




Ending up this review I want to spend a couple of words on Idea Factory, the makers of this game. 
IF has been a role model for japanese devs who want to port their games on steam, they started with some games being buggy due to their inexperience but they always tried their best to fix each one and learn from their mistakes. In the last two years they have shown their respect for the steam userbase by having games coming out well polished (doing even closed beta events that you can register to to help their test the game) and never censored, and by having fair pricings with up to -40% on launch for at least their last 4 games (maybe more, I honestly don't remember). 
If you're an anime fan and you want more and more japanese games being ported on steam in my opinion this is a great company to support.

26602107.review:
-FREE SPOILER REVIEW FOR FANS OF THE SERIES (that played R;B1&2-

[h1]TL;DR: More nep-nep & more improvements[/h1]

Well I just finished the game a few days ago and I can definitely say that this is the best installment of the first 3 games (not counting spin-offs). Clearly CH and IF learned from their mistakes and got a better game because of that. Amoung the improvements since the re;birth 1 there are:

[list]
[*]Longer story
[*]Post end-game content besides just the coliseum, now there are some alternative stories you can do!
[*]NG+ whenever you feel like (after ending the main story the game doesnt shove down your throat the NG+ to continue, you get to the world map and there is an event which gives you the option if you want to) (amazing improv if you ask me)
[*]More stella's dungeon and with much more control over how much you want to travel/risk.
[*]No more google searching those annoying materials, you can know where you gather the materials for those helpful plans, be it a dungeon, a quest, shop, etc. Also if you CAN'T get it at the time it will tell you.
[*]More nep-nep! (thank god)
[*]More & new characters on the main story which you will bring new comedy and situations
[*]Now featuers challanges, doing certain amount of X with each character will reward you with plans and stats (which could do some difference but not enough to make you feel you are being forced into it)
[*]+1 combo comands, being a total of 4 instead of 3
[*]Hidden treasures are now not so hidden and you dont need to spam a button like an idiot through out the entire dungeon to find only one and to the luck of RNG-sus (on that note plans and items within this are a bit more easy so they dont feel just as punishing and trivial tho still a bit hard)
[*]Dungeon desing is much more inspiring than before and less plain, now jumping actually is a thing and not just for candy eye on peeping [spoiler]in which at any case the developers are well aware of it and even you unlock a plan to exactly that after jumping 100 times[/spoiler]
[*]All the characters (markers) of R;B2 are on the game and FOR FREE!
[*]Bosses are more likely to use spells everyonce in a while [spoiler](they are still kinda plain and you can brute force your way through but I'm sure they will get with something more satisfaying)[/spoiler]
[*]EXE drive is a bit nerfed and more focused on coupling and formation in order to execute
[*]Questing is a bit more relevant on the main story though not quite related
[*]Less endings but you have more control over it with less requirements and is more intuitive, so you may not need to read guides for it
[*]Also [b][u]you can't be locked out[/u][/b] of an ending [spoiler](read conquest ending R;B2)[/spoiler]
[/list]

Well that wraps around the most important things I noticed (and remember at the time being). It's a must buy for anyone, be it fans of the series and friendly for newcomers (tho I still recomend starting on the R;B1 to appreciate all the improv over the franchise)

26433188.review:
**DISCLAIMER: This is my third review overall. I might make no sense in some of these lines. YOU'VE BEEN WARNED.**
As someone who started with the Hyperdimension Neptunia Victory on PS3 for the first out of the Neptunia series, I was really on for a treat. I also played the previous two Re;Birth games, and I can only tell this was going to be a great game overall.

For starters, this was based on the best Neptunia game I played back overall (the two Re;Birth games were fun, but not that much fun), meaning that I was going to enjoy the upgrades for this game. It included an extra chapter (which was ridiculous), some extra scenes that were pure fun (but not as fun as a certain side quest) and even characters the original Victory did not have (being the four Oracles of MKII/Re;Birth 2). And with messing around with the Plans, you could just do stuff like skipping battles (given you're a much higher level) when you Symbol Attack enemies, make the game relatively easier/harder, double EXP/G obtained and much more.

If you want a game that is comedic with serious moments and you just want to beat this game, you can absolutely get this. Just be warned; there is fanservice here and there. A LOT OF FANSERVICE. (Especially when you get to meet Iris Heart the first time...)

Also, this game comes with the DLCs of Victory; new characters, new weapons/armor, Level-limit breaks (now it's up to 999 instead of 99), and if you try the DLC dungeons, be sure to grind a lot. And when I say a lot, I mean nearly 400~800 Lv will suffice...(?)

26424008.review:
One of the best written, funniest rpgs of all time, and my 4th favorite jrpg i've ever played.  (behind Chrono Trigger, Persona 4, and Final Fantasy 4 respectively)  

Runs extremely well on just about anything, without the freeze bugs I ran into on the vita.  Uses the same quick, fun combat as the previous rebirth titles (which replaced 1 and 2's original combat with this game's)

Has 29 playable characters (though only 7ish are central to the plot) and my first run took around 45 hours, due to some built in cheats (via a crafting system) and ng+ subsequent runs for achievements are much quicker, taking 4-5 hours or so if skipping cutscenes.  Combat is basic, but fun, and reasonably challenging until you get overleveled (which will happen) the ability to skip all animations with the left shoulder button (or tab i think?) helps speed things along as well once you start to tire of the flashy animations 30 hours into the game.

I loved the unique plot that spans several decades of the character's lives with a slow burn of a conflict that uses that timespan to resolve itself in clever, unusual ways you don't often see in jrpgs.

And goddamn is it funny (if you like that sort of dumb, anime style comedy) I have never laughed out loud so much during a game (other than maybe portal)  

Play it! do it for plutie!


Main differences between this and Victory (ps3 version)

Much more voiced dialogue (though its still nowhere near 100% of the game)

All old dlc is now free and included (the only pay dlc is a cheat pack for a dollar.)

slightly different opening (a new tutorial dungeon)

a new post game story arc (relatively short mind you, one dungeon and boss after several cutscenes)

the scout system is replaced by the less confusing, but still annoying stella's tower, which operates somewhat similarly with some rougelike elements.

the synth system is replaced by the remake system used in the other remake games, it also 
replaces the flags, allowing you to just toggle them on and off instead of spamming scout missions to ge ttheir effects.

runs at 60fps (vita runs at 30ish)  as opposed to the 15ish of the original. (and 15ish is being real generous)



(side note, i know I only have an hour or so in game, but thats because this is my third copy, I have well over a hundred hour in the ps3 and vita versions and platinum trophies in each, but I only just recently bought the steam version)

I've been through the rocky road of the neptunia series from rebirth 1. I can say they have slowly made improvements in gameplay mechanics, graphics, and the story. The parodic humor has been consistant throughout the series so far, but unfortunately the constistency of content still applies to the same old recycled dungeons and reskined monsters. 

Rebirth 3 is probably my favorte one so far. The story has more depth while making more sense, and character development seems to flow more smoothly unlike neptunia 1 and 2. The new character Plutia was a refreshing addition as her humor was the most intesting of all. I am planning on getting the 4th installment of neptunia during sale time, so I hope they made more improvents in content rather then reusing some stuffs in thier most polish finish product.

As for my recommendation, this game isn't for a particular group of audience (westerners mainly). There are many obvious turn offs and understanding of jokes because of cultural differences and interests. Aside from that, I do get an old final fantasy and fire emblem gameplay mix vibe from it, so that is probably why I like and continue to play through all the neptunia games. The old ATB, simplistic gameplay design, and the special attacks (.EXE skill attacks) resemble that of limit break moments like final fantasy 7,8, and 10. I give it all a 8/10!

25745707.review:
Hyperdimension neptunia Re;birth3 is the sequel to MkII/Re;bith2 Sister generation, rather than being set in a different universe, Re;birth3/Victory is a continuation from MkII
After Gear and the candidates succesfully destroyed the Deity of Sin, peace returned to Gamindustri for quite some time, that is, until an anti-CPU group, led by Rei Rhyghts appears, at first, she's pretty klutzy, that is, until Neptune gets sent to another dimension, known as the Ultradimension, there, Planeptune and Lowee were the only nations, as for Lastation and Leanbox being created during the plot, the ruler of UltraPlaneptune is Plutia, a lazy, sleepy and adorable CPU who's transformation is a complete 360 of her personality, together, along with the Ultradimension counterparts of Blanc, Noire and Vert, Nep must find a way to return home
The Gameplay has been kept the same as Re;birth's 1 and 2, so only slight differences may vary, for example, a character's EXE attack can only be used if they have a bar filled in their SP bar, so instead of having 4 EXE bars, you could have 16 EXE attacks depending on if you use them, non-CPU characters have access to an awakened state, which powers them up, and of course, we have the challenges, from staying out of battle to jumping "x" amount of times in the areas
Re;birth3 has really great jokes and solid writing (IMHO), though i would still suggest jumping into the series from Re;birth2 if you want to make sense of the plot (especially for Megadimension)
Overall: Re;birth3 is another great remake of the mainstream neptunia games (This is Victory BTW), buy it if you like Neptunia, or if you want Sadie to spank you at night

25594928.review:
Out of all Re:Birth games I've played so far, this is my second favorite after the first Re;Birth. There are also some good features that make this one a little better:

-The new SP system, which needs a bit of effort to fill up without items at first (Unless you have drill, which makes you god-like), but gives every party member their own exe drive, so you can use multiple ultimate attacks in a row.

-Using four characters at once instead of just three. Not sure why they didn't do that with the first one though.

-This time you're allowed to choose between keep playing after finishing the story or start next game cycle instead of pulling you straight into the beggining of the story again.

-They added a feature to let you track which monsters have that specific drop you're looking for

-Those little plans to customize your game that make playing it all the better with your favorite character.

-Good soundtrack, from awesome battle tracks to funny or casual music during cutscenes.

-More Nep...what's not to love about that?

Now as much as I love this game and could keep going on and on about it, it has it's flaws:

-Some 3D scenes or battles can get laggy when fighting with everyone in HDD mode, especially around the ending.

-The game and grinding might get slow and repetitive after a while, especially around the last levels.

-The true ending can be complex to get without a guide to help you. And even then you might have to do a few game cycles before getting it.

-In Re;Birth 1 and 2 they added Processors to give Noire's HDD form her pigtails hairstyle from Victory, but didn't bother doing it the other way around in this game...not really a flaw, but fans of her original hairstyle (like me) would have loved it.

-A lot of people wanted a DLC that let you have Rei Ryghts as a playable character, but that never happened. Again, not a flaw. But indeed something that would have made a lot of people happy if added.

Conclussion:

As a fan of the franchise, I might be overlooking some flaws. And this game isn't really for those searching for a dark, serious story. But nonetheless, it's a fun and entertaining game to play, and I recommend it for everyone looking for a good RPG-Visual Novel hybrid coupled with a few laughs.

25229379.review:
If you didn't play Re;Birth 1 and 2, you probably should do so before playing 3. You're gonna miss a lot of humor referencing past games, involving characters like Nepgear and Arfoire.

So what changed? Not much really. Gameplay wise, the biggest change is the SP bar, that you now use to activate exe drive and recharge with rush attacks. I really like it, because I always felt the SP bar was quite useless. I never consumed all my SP in previous games, but now it's something you need to manage.
There are now Challenges (slay x foes, fight x battles, nothing hard really), that you'll need to complete to unlock bonuses - AND YOUR EXE DRIVES! - so be prepared to grind a lot. 
A lot of people said this game is easy. I disagree. Boss battles can be unforgiving and you're probably gonna get oneshot by Badd... By Anony... By Yellow Heart... See where I'm going? Of course if you're gonna play with the 4 oracles (they are quite OP), weaken enemies and super exp up, then yes, it will probably be easy. I don't know why you would do that, but whatever floats your boat.
Just a couple of new dungeons: Lowee is gorgeous, but the "Blocky Pixelated Hills" should come with a vomit alert. Not because it's bad, but because it's nauseating to navigate.
Stella's dungeon works generally better, even without blast exploring and death insurance, but it's still your typical idle game that will save you tons of material farming.
You can now see from inside the game where the plans materials are.
Lily ranks are stupid once again. I played around 70 hours and I didn't even raise ONE of those. And the fact that there's about 20 characters is really aggravating in this regard.

Story wise, it's quite alright but be warned. There'll be A LOT of talking. I mean, WAY more than the previous games. I have mixed feelings about it. I like watching the characters interact, but I can't say that watching Plutia spend 5 minutes to finish a single sentence is fun. 
And of course it's fun is its integrity. There are a lot of jokes, video game references, and a surprising amount of talk about boobs. Yes, there IS fanservice, roughly the same as RE;Birth 2.
There's no breaking the 4th wall because there's barely any 4th wall at all. Nepnep goes wild in this installment.
New enemies are quite memorable: Copy is one of the best things in the entire game.

So yeah. Buy Hyperdimension Neptunia RE;Birth 3 right now, it's quite cheap for more than a hundred hours of fun.

25091162.review:
The third installment of the Re;Birth series improved very much compared to the previous titles. For instance, the UI changed quite much (in a good way) or Stella's Dungeon, a mini-game, from the 2nd title requires less time to complete (for an archievement).
They added new things, too, like "challanges" where you can gain stats boost for completing certain task like running a certain amount of distance, killing a fixed amount of monsters and so on. 
From the free DLC (almost?) every character from past installments are available (that's a lot).
The music in this game is good, too, especially the battle themes.
If you played the previous games, you will notice, that the dungeons looks pretty much the same. There are only a few new looking dungeons.
The gameplay itself didn't changed much, so for those who are familiar with this series can dive in instantly.
The battle system is fun, but you might need a bit of grinding.
Storywise it is packed with funny jokes, although the translation seems to be a bit off, noticeable on Nep's (the main character) lines. Her IQ seems to have dropped by several points through translation.
Some archievements take time to get, but with the right equipment it's not too much time consuming.

So, this game was a fun JRPG experience and a worthy sequel.

24753667.review:
[h1]Score: 7.5/10[/h1]

[b][u]Similar Games[/u][/b]
Hyperdimension Neptunia Re;Birth 1 & 2

[b][u]Story[/u][/b]
Nep is being lazy. Histoire gets mad and orders her to get out and learn how to become better at her just and just not be lazy basically. A organization has forms that is against the CPUs and wishes for the people to rule themselves with laws. Nep is sent to another dimension by some form of magic. She must find a way to get back home.

[b][u]The Good[/u][/b]
The combat is the best it's been in the series. The content is greater than the previous titles. The story is easily better than the first game, but I probably liked the darker second game story better still. The humor is back in full force. Stella is actually a very good part of the game... assuming you buy the DLC. Several endings again. Tons of unlockables again. I love how often it breaks the fourth wall and doesn't take itself seriously.

[b][u]The Bad[/u][/b]
Performance on my end was poor even on a high end rig since evidently this has issues on AMD cards. The level resources are basically all from the previous titles. I wish they used tile sets or something so they were at least a little different. The DLC is basically required for Stella to be tollerable. The grind as always returns if you want the true ending. The voice acting is probably about the same, but because this game has more story scenes  it means even more are not voiced.

[b][u]Conclusion[/u][/b]
Easily the best of the Re;Birth games, but not without issues. The main issue is that if you played through the previous titles you will be getting tired of the same levels in every game. Also why would you make Stella suck so hard unless you download the DLC? It's a freaking dollar, but seriously why? Even so I'm glad this game has a loyal steam following. It's truly hard to find a game with great humor.
